# The Practice Area Where Biglaw Partner Billing Rates Climbed Highest
## Wait till you see their hourly rates....
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 30, 2023 at 4:42 PMMay 30, 2023 at 4:16 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/the-practice-area-where-biglaw-partner-billing-rates-climbed-highest/&text=The%20Practice%20Area%20Where%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Billing%20Rates%20Climbed%20Highest)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/the-practice-area-where-biglaw-partner-billing-rates-climbed-highest/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/the-practice-area-where-biglaw-partner-billing-rates-climbed-highest/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Trivia Question of the Day!](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/)

According to the latest LexisNexis CounselLink report, Biglaw partner billing rates are surging in certain practice areas. In 2022, which practice area had the highest percentage rate increase?

Hint: While the average partner billable rate increased by 4.5% overall, four major practice areas saw median partner hourly rates climb by higher than 5%.

# Biglaw Firm Gathers Associates For 'Major News,' Then Doesn't Announce Bonuses
## What were they thinking?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 6, 2018 at 11:16 AMDecember 6, 2018 at 10:44 AM
16
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-firm-gathers-associates-for-major-news-then-doesnt-announce-bonuses/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Gathers%20Associates%20For%20‘Major%20News,’%20Then%20Doesn’t%20Announce%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-firm-gathers-associates-for-major-news-then-doesnt-announce-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-firm-gathers-associates-for-major-news-then-doesnt-announce-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This summer, while the rest of the Biglaw world dutifully raised associate salaries to reflect the cost of living increase of the last two years, Greenberg Traurig bucked the trend and spun a song and dance about the economy that boiled down to “[we’re too cheap to pay you](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/greenberg-traurig-explains-why-its-too-cheap-to-raise-associate-salaries/).” The firm later [tried to pay off a few attorneys](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/having-promised-to-not-follow-the-market-this-firm-is-trying-to-quietly-pay-a-lucky-few/), but more or less just ate the black eye it’d given itself functionally admitting — not so much that they couldn’t afford this raise, but that it couldn’t really afford the 2016 raise it already gave associates in its New York and Chicago offices. Because [that’s what a firm really means](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/why-the-milbank-raise-is-not-that-big-of-a-deal-and-why-it-is/) when they don’t offer a cost of living adjustment.

Armed with the knowledge that Greenberg Traurig is absolutely, positively not interested in employee satisfaction if it costs them a penny, associates were appropriately steeled for the bait and switch dropped on them this week.

On Tuesday, associates were called together for an all associates video conference, the sort of drudgery that attorneys go through this time of year because it usually corresponds with a happy bonus announcement. Indeed, the powers-that-be teased the assembled masses on this score with a tantalizing “if you stay around until the end of the presentation, we’ll have some major news to announce.” Well, well, what might that major news be in this first week of December two weeks removed from the start of bonus season?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The firm will be bringing back associate retreats. If ever there was a [one-year membership in the Jelly of the Month Club](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1K8-kNuDgoA) in Biglaw, this is surely it.

So now we must ask ourselves the classic corporate query: is Greenberg Traurig’s leadership team is evil or stupid? For it would certainly take someone with a heart two sizes too small to explicitly stoke associate excitement knowing that the punchline would not be cash but an all-expense paid trip to spend more time with all the assholes from the office.

And yet, Greenberg Traurig’s chronic failure to get through the day without alienating its employees has to stem from a deeper misunderstanding of their surroundings. Do they not see the bonus talk? Perhaps not, since bonus announcements [aren’t flying with their usual rapidity](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/what-have-we-learned-from-biglaw-bonus-season-so-far/). Still, it is December. Can they be so dense as to not realize that the only things that pass for “major news” for firms this month are bonuses or layoffs?

Evil or stupid? You decide.

#  Failing Well: Tips For A Successful Career In Law
## Regardless of your performance, it’s always possible to learn from your mistakes.
By [Olga V. Mack](https://abovethelaw.com/author/olgamack/)  
onMay 16, 2022 at 12:44 PMMay 16, 2022 at 11:51 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/failing-well-tips-for-a-successful-career-in-law/&text= Failing%20Well:%20Tips%20For%20A%20Successful%20Career%20In%20Law)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/failing-well-tips-for-a-successful-career-in-law/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/failing-well-tips-for-a-successful-career-in-law/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In order to be successful in law, you must learn how to fail better. Many lawyers become so focused on winning every case that they lose sight of the bigger picture. Real success requires you to take risks and learn from your failures. So don’t be afraid to make mistakes; they’re the only way you can learn and grow.

Here are a few tips that can help you learn from missteps and limitations, becoming a better lawyer in the process:

Don’t Be Afraid To Take Risks

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The best way to learn is by taking risks. If you’re always playing it safe, you’ll never truly grow. So, make a point of taking chances and watch your skills improve. If you’re given the opportunity to take on a new and challenging case, go for it! Taking on next-level experiences is how you learn and grow as a lawyer.

Learn From Your Failures

It’s important to remember that not every case is going to be a victory. You’re going to lose some cases, and that’s okay. What’s important is that you learn from your failures.

Try to take the time to debrief after every case — win or lose. What could you have done differently? What went well? What didn’t go well? By taking the time to reflect on your failures, you can learn from them, adjust your approach next time and become a better lawyer.

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Be Patient

Rome wasn’t built in a day, and neither is a successful career in law. That takes time, patience, and perseverance — all things that don’t come quickly. Don’t expect to become a top lawyer overnight.

Take the time to build relationships with clients and colleagues, and don’t get discouraged if you don’t see results immediately. Good things come to those who wait.

Have Realistic Expectations

Part of being patient is having realistic expectations. As mentioned, cases don’t always end up in your favor. Someone has to lose every case and, sometimes, that someone is you. Regardless of your performance, it’s always possible to learn from your mistakes.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

From Pilot and Above The Law

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Don’t put too much pressure on yourself. Just do the best you can and remember that negative outcomes can still lead to positive lessons learned.

Stay Focused On The Bigger Picture

It’s easy to get caught up in the day-to-day grind of being a lawyer, working hard on short-term goals and losing sight of the long term. But it’s important to remember the big picture. Why did you become a lawyer? What do you ultimately want to accomplish in your career?

If you start to lose sight of the bigger picture, take a step back and remember what drove you to become a lawyer in the first place. This will help you stay focused and motivated, even when things are tough.

Conclusion

It is important for lawyers to learn from their failures if they want to cultivate successful careers in law. By understanding the reasons why they failed, they can avoid making the same mistakes in the future.

Additionally, it is important for lawyers to set realistic goals and be willing to adapt strategies that are not working. Lastly, lawyers should always remember that the practice of law is constantly evolving, so they need to be prepared to change with it.

For more information on how to fail better as a lawyer, be sure to watch the [“Fail Better – The importance of a growth mindset](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D8uTiQlqoOc)” Notes to My (Legal) Self episode where Victoria Libin discusses the important role of failure in learning and growing.


Olga V. Mack is the CEO of [Parley Pro](https://parleypro.com/), a next-generation contract management company that has pioneered online negotiation technology. Olga embraces legal innovation and had dedicated her career to improving and shaping the future of law. She is convinced that the legal profession will emerge even stronger, more resilient, and more inclusive than before by embracing technology. Olga is also an award-winning general counsel, operations professional, startup advisor, public speaker, adjunct professor, and entrepreneur. She founded the [Women Serve on Boards](https://www.womenserveonboards.com/) movement that advocates for women to participate on corporate boards of Fortune 500 companies. She authored [Get on Board: Earning Your Ticket to a Corporate Board Seat](https://www.amazon.com/Get-Board-Earning-Ticket-Corporate/dp/1949991407) and [Fundamentals of Smart Contract Security](https://www.amazon.com/Fundamentals-Smart-Contract-Security-Richard-ebook/dp/B07S8YF27G). You can follow Olga on Twitter @olgavmack.

# Biglaw Managing Partner Ditches Firm Life To Aid Refugee Children
## Time to give back.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 24, 2023 at 4:46 PMJanuary 24, 2023 at 2:41 PM
11
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/biglaw-managing-partner-ditches-firm-life-to-aid-refugee-children/&text=Biglaw%20Managing%20Partner%20Ditches%20Firm%20Life%20To%20Aid%20Refugee%20Children)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/biglaw-managing-partner-ditches-firm-life-to-aid-refugee-children/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/biglaw-managing-partner-ditches-firm-life-to-aid-refugee-children/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[Reed Smith](https://www.reedsmith.com/en) global managing partner [Alexander “Sandy” Thomas](https://www.reedsmith.com/en/professionals/t/thomas-alexander-y) announced that he’s leaving the firm he’s managed for the past decade to serve as the chief legal officer of [KIND](https://supportkind.org/), short for “Kids In Need of Defense.” The organization advocates for refugee and immigrant children, including providing free legal defense to children facing immigration proceedings, despite the Department of Justice’s insistence that [3-year-olds can competently represent themselves in legal proceedings](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/doj-official-3-year-olds-can-competently-represent-themselves/).

Yes, that’s [actually something a senior Justice Department official has said](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/can-a-3-year-old-represent-herself-in-immigration-court-this-judge-thinks-so/2016/03/03/5be59a32-db25-11e5-925f-1d10062cc82d_story.html).

Thomas leaves Reed Smith having grown revenue from [$1.152 billion in revenue in 2014 to $1.44 billion in 2021](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/01/24/reed-smith-global-managing-partner-to-leave-firm-for-clo-role/) and delivered a little over half a million dollar increase in profits per equity partner. He will be replaced at the firm by [Catherine “Casey” Ryan](https://www.reedsmith.com/en/professionals/r/ryan-casey) — what’s with all the nicknames over there? — the current global head of legal personnel.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Seemingly [a smoother transition than the one that installed Thomas](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/06/a-leadership-battle-at-a-biglaw-firm/)!

“This is a chance to take my career and my life as as a lawyer in a new direction,” Thomas said. Ryan applauded Thomas’ tenure, calling him a “strong, steady and inspirational leader for this firm.”

Congratulations to all.

[Reed Smith Global Managing Partner to Leave Firm for CLO Role](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/01/24/reed-smith-global-managing-partner-to-leave-firm-for-clo-role/)

# This Biglaw Associate Has A Nearly Perfect NCAA Bracket
## Your bracket is probably busted, but hers is still going strong.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 27, 2019 at 2:14 PMMarch 27, 2019 at 12:26 PM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/this-biglaw-associate-has-a-nearly-perfect-ncaa-bracket/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Associate%20Has%20A%20Nearly%20Perfect%20NCAA%20Bracket)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/this-biglaw-associate-has-a-nearly-perfect-ncaa-bracket/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/this-biglaw-associate-has-a-nearly-perfect-ncaa-bracket/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I fill out brackets every year. I filled out four brackets this year, and I was doing really well on ESPN, but when [LSU] won, I lost that perfect bracket. Then I realized I had a bracket on Politico that was still perfect, and then it stayed perfect.

I think at one point I was one of 8 people in the country who had a perfect bracket left, and then I lost out in the Villanova game, so I had 38 correct picks in a row. I think the most ever up to that point had been 39, but right now there’s still one guy out there who has a perfect bracket.

So it’s not so much that I’m a basketball savant, as it’s kind of a Slumdog Millionaire kind of thing. [Laughs] It’s a confluence of forces. I looked at the picks, I looked at the Nate Silver blog, and then I kind of just went with my gut.

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
— [Meghan Hammond](https://www.pillsburylaw.com/en/lawyers/meghan-hammond.html), an associate at Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman, commenting on her [unexpected success in her NCAA men’s basketball tournament brackets](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/03/26/pillsbury-associate-picks-near-perfect-ncaa-bracket/) this year. She’s gotten 46 out of 48 matchups right thus far in Politico Playbook’s NCAA pool. Hammond, an alumnus of the University of Tennessee, has the team going to the finals.

# 107-Year-Old Biglaw Attorney Dies Of Coronavirus Complications
## He loved the time he spent at his firm -- more than 83 years of it.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 26, 2020 at 1:42 PMSeptember 1, 2021 at 11:57 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/107-year-old-biglaw-attorney-dies-of-coronavirus-complications/&text=107-Year-Old%20Biglaw%20Attorney%20Dies%20Of%20Coronavirus%20Complications)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/107-year-old-biglaw-attorney-dies-of-coronavirus-complications/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/107-year-old-biglaw-attorney-dies-of-coronavirus-complications/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

There comes a time in every lawyer’s life when they wish they could leave their firm because it feels like they’ve been there forever. [Mordecai “Mordie” Rochlin](https://www.paulweiss.com/professionals/partners-and-counsel/mordecai-rochlin), a tax and estates lawyer at Paul Weiss who retired about 37 years ago, but still worked at the firm as of counsel, was at his firm forever, and he credited the firm with enriching his very long life.

Rochlin, 107, recently passed away due to coronavirus complications (specifically respiratory failure, with viral pneumonia caused by COVID-19). According to research done by the firm, Rochlin was 20th oldest man in the country. He was just six weeks shy of his 108th birthday. Firm chairman Brad Karp referred to Rochlin as a “real treasure,” calling him the “embodiment of the history of Paul Weiss.”

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Born in 1912, Rochlin was one of the oldest lawyers in New York, and until his death on October 23, he was the only person to have known and worked with all five of the name partners at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.

Rochlin would [spend a few days a week](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/the-never-ending-billable-hour-a-106-year-old-is-still-working-at-the-biglaw-firm-where-he-started-his-career/) at the firm in his office on the 32nd floor signing checks, reading memos, and making phone calls, but would stay there for an hour and a half at most — after all, at his age, doing that kind of work was tiring. He remembered Paul Weiss history with “uncanny detail” and one of his stories appears in the [New York Law Journal](https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2020/10/23/mordie-rochlin-who-embodied-paul-weiss-history-dies-at-107/):

During his 107th birthday celebration last year, Rochlin also recalled the fortuitous meeting of firm partners right after the death of Louis Weiss, who worked as Marshall Field’s attorney and was the firm’s most prominent rainmaker. Rochlin, who had just been named a partner, sat on the floor of a room with the other partners at the Gramercy Park Hotel to discuss the firm’s future.

“The first question to be decided was are we going to remain as a firm despite the enormous loss of Louis Weiss,” Rochlin said. He said Simon H. Rifkind, a former federal judge who’d joined the firm earlier that year, was critical in making the case the firm could carry forward.

“It was a tremendous event in my life and the life of the firm,” Rochlin said.

At his last birthday celebration, Rochlin said, “Without the firm, I would have probably shriveled up somewhere in a nursing home and have long been put away.”

# 'Muffy, He’s Murdering Me': Law Firm Managing Partner Testifies Against Lawyer Accused Of Slitting His Throat
## That one lawyer could allegedly do such things to two members of the bar is disturbing.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 24, 2016 at 11:02 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/muffy-hes-murdering-me-law-firm-managing-partner-testifies-against-lawyer-accused-of-slitting-his-throat/&text=‘Muffy,%20He’s%20Murdering%20Me’:%20Law%20Firm%20Managing%20Partner%20Testifies%20Against%20Lawyer%20Accused%20Of%20Slitting%20His%20Throat)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/muffy-hes-murdering-me-law-firm-managing-partner-testifies-against-lawyer-accused-of-slitting-his-throat/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/muffy-hes-murdering-me-law-firm-managing-partner-testifies-against-lawyer-accused-of-slitting-his-throat/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Andrew Schmuhl

Lawyer Andrew Schmuhl stands accused of breaking into the home of [Leo S. Fisher](http://www.beankinney.com/people-Leo-Fisher.html), the managing partner of Northern Virginia firm [Bean Kinney & Korman](http://www.beankinney.com/), and committing extremely violent acts once inside. Schmuhl has been on trial for the past week in Fairfax County, Virginia.

In case you’re unfamiliar with the case, Schmuhl and his wife, Alecia (who is also an attorney), allegedly plotted revenge against Bean Kinney’s managing partner because [Alecia had been fired from the firm](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/11/husband-and-wife-attorney-duo-accused-of-stabbing-law-firms-managing-partner/). Fisher and his wife, Susan Duncan (who is also a lawyer), were brutally stabbed numerous times, and Duncan was shot in the head. Both were grievously injured with life-threatening wounds, but survived the attacks. Their disturbing testimony has captured the attention of the NoVa bar since Schmuhl’s trial began on May 16. Schmuht has been charged with abduction, aggravated malicious wounding, using a firearm, and burglary.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Fisher first recounted the tale of how Schmuhl allegedly tied his wrists and ankles with plastic zip ties and did the same to his wife. Shortly thereafter, he said, Schmuhl brought Fisher into his home office and ordered him to go through his work email account, desperately searching for an email Schmuhl claimed the law firm partner had sent to a Mexican drug cartel called the Knights Templar to “put a hit on somebody for $370,000.” It was then that Schmuhl began to ask Fisher why he had recently fired an associate from the firm — his wife, Alecia Schmuhl.

Fisher says Schmuhl received cellphone calls throughout the entirety of the ordeal, and his assailant later asked the law firm partner where his stacks of money and gold were located. After Fisher denied having any cash or gold, things took a turn for the worse.

Here’s some of Fisher’s chilling testimony, courtesy of the [Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2016/05/23/mclean-home-invasion-victim-says-he-recognized-his-attacker-quickly/):

Fisher said he thought maybe the man just wanted money, and offered to go to the bank. “I was just sitting there like this,” Fisher testified from the witness stand. “My heart was pounding. I said to him, ‘I may be having a heart attack.’” (Fisher had suffered a heart attack the previous year.) “Next thing I know he knocks me over backwards, puts the pillow over me and he cuts my throat and stabs me.” He said he was stabbed in the left side of the head and in the left shoulder.

Fisher yelled out, “Muffy, he’s murdering me,” using a nickname for his wife, but he said the pillow may have muffled that. He said the man mocked him and said, “What is this, the Muppets?”

Susan Duncan’s testimony is no less frightening. The [Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2016/05/19/mclean-home-invasion-victim-intruder-would-jump-on-me-and-stab-me-over-and-over/) has the details:

Duncan, sobbing, continued in court: “I saw he had a gun in his hand. I felt the bullet. I fell down on the floor.” She had been grazed by a shot. The man left the bedroom.

“I started crawling across the bed” to reach a phone, Duncan testified through tears. “He jumped on the bed and started stabbing me. So I collapsed and he got off. So I got up and he would jump on me and stab me over and over. And he would get off. This happened three or four times.” Finally, she played dead and the man left the room.

That one lawyer could allegedly do such things to two members of the bar is disturbing.

Schmuhl, who was found with his wife, Alecia, after police stopped them in the highway as they fled from the scene, was seated in the passenger seat wearing only an adult diaper. Schmuhl will be pursuing an involuntary intoxication defense, and his lawyers will claim that the former Army JAG officer was taking 14 prescribed medications for a prior injury that “made him unaware of what he was doing.” Alecia, who faces the same charges, is accused of being the mastermind of the attack, but she is expected to claim in her own defense that Schmuhl was manipulating her. Alecia will stand trial in September.

Do you have any additional information about Alecia and Andrew Schmuhl? We may use it anonymously in an upcoming story here on Above the Law. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Alecia%20and%20Andrew%20Schmuhl), text us at (646) 820-8477, or tweet us [@atlblog](https://twitter.com/atlblog). Thanks for your assistance.

# Morning Docket: 08.08.22
## * Former Justice Breyer thinks the Rule of Law needs some saving. [[Law360.com](https://www.law360.com/articles/1517597/breyer-calls-on-lawyers-to-stand-up-for-rule-of-law)] * Biglaw's big bucks, while still big, are noticeably less so. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/08/08/early-warning-arises-as-law-firm-profits-fall-again/)] * Indiana just put a major abortion ban in place. What now? [[NPR](https://www.npr.org/2022/08/08/1116264186/what-legal-implications-arise-after-indiana-approves-an-abortion-ban)] * A success of the #Metoo movement: DC law empowers young adults. [[Wa Po](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2022/08/05/dc-has-new-law-help-student-victims-sexual-assault/)] * Thoreau in 2022: Some doctors are deciding Hippocrates may be more important than Dobbs. [[The Intercept](https://theintercept.com/2022/08/06/abortion-bans-doctors-civil-disobedience/)]
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)

# Maryanne Trump Barry Pulled A Kozinski
## The rule of law is not having a good year.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 12, 2019 at 11:45 AMApril 12, 2019 at 11:31 AM
36
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/maryanne-trump-barry-pulled-a-kozinski/&text=Maryanne%20Trump%20Barry%20Pulled%20A%20Kozinski)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/maryanne-trump-barry-pulled-a-kozinski/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/maryanne-trump-barry-pulled-a-kozinski/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Donald Trump and Judge Maryanne Trump Barry (ED Jones/AFP/Getty Images).

The president’s sister, Judge Maryanne Trump Barry, apparently left her seat on the Third Circuit earlier this year. Barry pulled off her February retirement without much fanfare, but people started to notice the judge’s absence this week. The 82-year-old judge apparently decided it was time to step aside, enjoy a blissful retirement, and squelch an investigation into her family’s long history of financial… issues.

Specifically, the NY Times’ report that built a detailed case that [Fred Trump broke all sorts of tax laws](https://www.vox.com/the-goods/2018/10/3/17934360/trump-taxes-illegal-new-york-times-expose) to set up his kids — including Judge Barry and the current president — with a tidy fortune. The president’s attorneys have branded the report defamatory. The president’s attorneys have not taken any action over this claim because, you know, “discovery.”

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Now, the government can’t prosecute someone for tax evasion that took place over 30 years ago, but the courts can launch an ethical inquiry into a sitting judge’s involvement in criminality.

And that’s what was happening and almost certainly why Judge Barry is now former Judge Barry. The court informed a complainant that the matter was [being looked into](https://www.vox.com/2019/4/11/18306167/maryanne-trump-barry-tax-returns-trump) as of February 1. She resigned on February 11, rendering the investigation moot.

If this move looks familiar, it’s because we saw the exact same maneuver when then-Judge Alex Kozinski bailed on his job to [squelch an investigation into sexual misconduct](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/breaking-judge-kozinski-is-retiring/).

Three cheers for the rule of law.

ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
How many federal judges are we at now where a recent “retirement” has prevented investigation/punishment & and they’re still receiving a full pension?
– Maryanne Barry
– Alex Kozinski
– Richard Roberts
– Any others?

This is not a good look, [@uscourts](https://twitter.com/uscourts?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw).

— Fix the Court (@FixTheCourt) [April 11, 2019](https://twitter.com/FixTheCourt/status/1116137825613877250?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

Oh, right. Let’s not forget that judges who preemptively resign in order to short-circuit investigations that could result in their impeachment [still get to hold onto their full pension](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/senator-pissed-basically-nothing-bad-happens-to-retired-federal-judges-accused-of-sexual-harassment/)! The taxpayers are still on the hook for paying a multimillionaire — potentially garnered through malfeasance — for life because she had the foresight to walk away before the investigation could get rolling.

America has truly been rendered great again.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joe@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news. # Top 20 Biglaw Firm Announces Additional Special Bonuses For Some Associates
## Is this the way that extra cash will flow through Biglaw this bonus season?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 28, 2021 at 10:01 AMOctober 28, 2021 at 4:04 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/paul-weiss-special-bonus-discretional/&text=Top%2020%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Announces%20Additional%20Special%20Bonuses%20For%20Some%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/paul-weiss-special-bonus-discretional/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/paul-weiss-special-bonus-discretional/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo via Getty Images)

Biglaw bonus season is nearly upon us, and the lateral market is hot, hot, hot. Associates are expecting bigger and better year-end bonuses than ever before, and they know if they don’t receive them, they’ll be happily welcomed at another firm that may be more willing to show them the money.

As far as special bonuses are concerned, however, associates don’t think they’ll be seeing them again. We released the results of our [annual bonus survey](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/biglaw-associates-expecting-bigger-better-bonuses-after-wild-year-of-billables/) just yesterday, and a little more than 55% of respondents reported that they do not believe any additional special bonuses will be offered. One firm just decided to blow associates’ expectations out of the water when it comes to special bonuses — but there’s a catch.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Last night, Paul Weiss informed all associates and counsel of a discretionary special bonus program, the key word there being discretionary.

In a memo announcing the special bonuses, chairman Brad Karp provided the details on those who may be eligible to receive them:

This special bonus is in addition to our class-year salaries and bonuses. It is designed to provide an additional reward for those associates and counsel who exhibited exceptional commitment in support of our firm and our clients during the first six months of 2021. Another special bonus payment for exceptional commitment covering the second half of 2021 will be distributed early next year.

Those receiving this special bonus will be notified by your practice group leaders the week of November 8th, and the payment will be reflected in your November 15th paycheck.

That’s right, Paul Weiss is offering associates and counsel two rounds of special bonus payments for extraordinary performance. It looks like congratulations are in order for some lawyers at the firm… but not all.

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
“They are doing it on a group by group basis like Skadden to make it harder to copy,” reports an insider at the firm. If you recall, Skadden has reportedly been [handing out retention bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/is-skadden-arps-handing-out-retention-bonuses-to-only-some-associates/) to associates in certain practice groups, but the firm has been keeping it rather hush-hush, with no memo to speak of acknowledging the program’s existence.

Are practice-based and performance-based special bonuses the only way that additional cash compensation will be flowing throughout Biglaw this bonus season? To be blunt, this may be the best that associates can hope for. The existing year-end bonus scale has had staying power for years on end, and for good reason: law firm leaders don’t want to set themselves up to fail if they’re unable to match the baseline bonus the following year.

Associates should keep an eye out for more special bonuses, but until a firm announces a payment grid, they shouldn’t expect them to be universal in nature.

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Paul Weiss.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm announces or matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# Associate Bonus Watch: No Chance This Wasn't Going To Happen
## Keeping up with the other members of the Magic Circle.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onDecember 1, 2016 at 10:52 AMDecember 1, 2016 at 10:54 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associate-bonus-watch-no-chance-this-wasnt-going-to-happen/&text=Associate%20Bonus%20Watch:%20No%20Chance%20This%20Wasn’t%20Going%20To%20Happen)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associate-bonus-watch-no-chance-this-wasnt-going-to-happen/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associate-bonus-watch-no-chance-this-wasnt-going-to-happen/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
After Allen & Overy [announced bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/associate-bonus-watch-the-first-magic-circle-firm-speaks/) following the [Cravath scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/associate-bonus-watch-cravath-announces-its-2016-associate-bonuses/), it was only a matter of time before another Magic Circle firm would follow suit. And not much time: Clifford Chance just announced a market match as well.

The memo, from regional managing partner [Evan Cohen](https://www.cliffordchance.com/people_and_places/people/partners/us/evan_cohen.html), is straightforward (and pretty much identical to [last year’s memo](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-matchmaker-matchmaker-make-me-a-match/)). Bonuses will be paid on January 13. We’ve posted the complete memo on the next page.

You know the drill: when your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”). We always keep our sources on bonus stories anonymous. There’s no need to send the memo using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. Please be sure to include the memo as proof; we like to post complete bonus memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. You can also text us if you prefer, at 646-820-8477.

(Flip to the next page for the full Clifford Chance bonus memo.)

# Morning Docket: 02.08.23
## * Just in time for Black History Month, white legislators impose new all white court system over Black voters. [[Mississippi Today](https://mississippitoday.org/2023/02/07/jackson-court-system-house-bill-1020/)] * Jury hears that Alex Murdaugh was bad at his job. Nepo babies, amiright? [[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/alex-murdaugh-colleagues-thought-sh-095144687.html)] * Whenever someone stupid tells you the First Amendment is under attack, remember that those same people want a prior restraint on "telling people that they can escape torture by getting asylum in the US" [[Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/government/states-urge-us-supreme-court-revive-ban-encouraging-illegal-immigration-2023-02-07/)] * Coinbase employee pleads guilty to insider trading. Who would have thought made up Ponzi schemes could attract the criminal element? [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/articles/1573613)] * Biglaw offices getting more efficient. Which is just a proxy for "realizing most people aren't coming into the office." [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2023/02/07/am-law-100-firms-have-room-for-improvement-in-making-offices-efficient/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onFebruary 8, 2023 at 9:22 AM

# Firm Kicks Off The Weekend With Raises
## Firm with some unique staff gets raises for the lawyers.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 17, 2016 at 5:48 PM
22
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/firm-kicks-off-the-weekend-with-raises/&text=Firm%20Kicks%20Off%20The%20Weekend%20With%20Raises)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/firm-kicks-off-the-weekend-with-raises/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/firm-kicks-off-the-weekend-with-raises/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Coming in just under the work week radar, we have another Boston raise.

In a [late afternoon memo](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/firm-kicks-off-the-weekend-with-raises/2/) from managing partners [Charles Cheever](https://www.choate.com/people/charles-cheever) and [Bill Gelnaw](https://www.choate.com/people/william-gelnaw), Choate Hall informed its attorneys that they too would be bumping up salaries “consistent with recent market changes” on July 1. The memo specifically cites a $180K salary for the newbies. Where the scale goes from there is not defined. Each associate will receive an individual memo later, so if we start hearing of inconsistencies with the full scale, we’ll update accordingly.

In a wrinkle specific to Choate’s noted IP expertise, Cheever and Gelnaw note that they haven’t yet decided what to do with salaries for the firm’s staff scientists and patent agents — critical employees in the IP world. It’s an angle I hadn’t considered until now, but IP firms do employ specialized staff that contribute to the firm’s work, and at a certain point they might not want salaries to get too out of balance.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Also under consideration is the firm’s handling of “lawyers who are on special arrangements.” Undoubtedly this deals with part-time lawyers or something like that, but we’re going to pretend Choate Hall has at least one associate seconded with the CIA infiltrating COBRA or KAOS because it’s Friday and this is the 300th salary increase post so it could use a little spice.

In the meantime, congratulations to the Choate Hall attorneys, and good luck to the scientists and patent agents!

Check out the [full memo on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/firm-kicks-off-the-weekend-with-raises/2/)…

Remember, when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Cravath) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Cravath”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# Turns Out Lawyers Despise Trump. Especially His Own.
## Oh, hai, Don McGahn!
By [Liz Dye](https://abovethelaw.com/author/edye/)  
onOctober 22, 2020 at 4:16 PMOctober 22, 2020 at 2:59 PM
46
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/turns-out-lawyers-despise-trump-especially-his-own/&text=Turns%20Out%20Lawyers%20Despise%20Trump.%20Especially%20His%20Own.)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/turns-out-lawyers-despise-trump-especially-his-own/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/turns-out-lawyers-despise-trump-especially-his-own/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Evan Vucci-Pool/Getty Images)

We hate him. We really, really hate him.

Reuters [analyzed](https://in.reuters.com/article/us-lawyer-election-donations/lawyers-spurn-trump-campaign-in-individual-donations-including-from-jones-day-idUSKBN27531P) FEC disclosures to see whether lawyers were clicking “Donate” at ActBlue or WinRed. Unsurprisingly, the party that is currently [burning down](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/dont-look-now-but-the-doj-may-be-ever-so-slightly-on-fire/) the Justice Department and smashing all political and professional norms is doing significantly worse with the counselor class.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Reuters reports that the Biden campaign raked in almost $29 million from lawyers from January 2019 through August of this year, compared to just $1.75 million for Trump. Those are just individual attorneys’ contributions to the campaigns directly, capped at $5,600 between the primary and general, and don’t include contributions to PACs or party committees.

Morgan & Morgan leads the pack with $369,127 for Biden during the period, followed by Covington & Burling at $240,564 and Sidley Austin at $230,686.

Attorneys at Fish & Richardson, Trump’s biggest supporters, could spare only $11,355 for the President, and they appear to have [hedged their bets](https://www.opensecrets.org/orgs/summary?id=D000033704) with equivalent donations to Biden as well. Even Attorney General Barr’s old partners at Kirkland & Ellis only kicked up $10,840 for his boss in the relevant period. Although, according to Open Secrets’ database, the running tally for all employees at the firm is currently at $364,283 for Biden, and $25,202 for Trump.

Worst of all, the lawyers who know Trump best — or at least the ones who take the most of his money — don’t like him either. During the 2020 campaign cycle, Jones Day was paid [$11,806,685](https://www.opensecrets.org/campaign-expenditures/vendor?cycle=2020&vendor=Jones+Day) by Republican candidates, committees, and PACs. The Trump campaign shelled out upwards of $4.5 million of that, with the RNC paying another $3.2 million. Nonetheless, lawyers at the firm sent only $50 dollars (no, we didn’t leave off a couple of zeroes) to the Trump campaign, and $90,000 to Biden.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
Hey, isn’t that former White House Counsel Don McGahn’s firm with the 1,800:1 Biden-Trump donation ratio? Incidentally, none of that cash came from McGahn himself, whose only donations [appear to be](https://www.fec.gov/data/receipts/individual-contributions/?contributor_name=Donald++mcgahn&min_date=01%2F01%2F2019&max_date=12%2F31%2F2020) $2,800 to WinRed and $2,800 to Susan Collins. (His wife [didn’t donate](https://www.fec.gov/data/receipts/individual-contributions/?contributor_name=Shannon+mcGahn&min_date=01%2F01%2F2019&max_date=12%2F31%2F2020) to the president either.)

Trump’s personal attorneys are only slightly less appalled at their most famous client — but only slightly. The ratio of donations from Kasowitz Benson Torres and Morgan, Lewis & Bockius is about 10:1 in favor of the former Vice President.

“It shouldn’t be news that rich, liberal lawyers in Biden’s pocket are desperately trying to make up for his lackluster candidacy or that every big law firm has lawyers on both sides of the political aisle,” Trump campaign spokeswoman Samantha Zager snarked to Reuters.

Which tells you exactly what she and her boss think of our community. And considering the publicly available information at the FEC, the feeling is apparently mutual.

[Lawyers spurn Trump campaign in individual donations, including from Jones Day](https://in.reuters.com/article/us-lawyer-election-donations/lawyers-spurn-trump-campaign-in-individual-donations-including-from-jones-day-idUSKBN27531P) [Reuters]

# BREAKING: Biglaw Bonuses Are Here!!!
## No, Cravath didn't make the first move this year.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 7, 2019 at 11:04 AMNovember 14, 2019 at 1:34 PM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/breaking-biglaw-bonuses-are-here/&text=BREAKING:%20Biglaw%20Bonuses%20Are%20Here!!!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/breaking-biglaw-bonuses-are-here/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/breaking-biglaw-bonuses-are-here/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Bonus season has officially arrived — and it’s here SUPER early!

It’s actually a bit shocking that Biglaw bonus season is here so soon. This is actually the earliest that Biglaw bonuses have been announced since 2009. But what comes as an even bigger shocker is the fact that Cravath was not the firm to make the first move on year-end bonuses. That’s right, Biglaw associates can once again thank the firm that [brought about the $190K salary scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/new-york-to-190k-no-cravath-didnt-make-the-first-move/) for their early bonuses. Thank you, Milbank!

So, let’s get into the details. What do the bonuses look like this year?

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Class of 2019 – $15,000 (pro-rated)
Class of 2018 – $15,000
Class of 2017 – $25,000
Class of 2016 – $50,000
Class of 2015 – $65,000
Class of 2014 – $80,000
Class of 2013 – $90,000
Class of 2012 – $100,000
Class of 2011 – $100,000

If you recall, these are the exact same bonuses that were handed out last year (and [72 percent](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/associate-bonus-watch-2019-bonus-season-is-here/) of our survey respondents thought this would be exactly what happened). But you may also recall that [earlier this week](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/are-biglaw-associates-billing-their-butts-off-for-disappointing-bonuses/), we reminded everyone that if 2019’s year-end bonuses were the same as last year’s, overall bonus compensation would be substantially lower than in 2018, since associates at many high-end firms also received special summer bonuses. Perhaps Cravath will come swooping in with some higher bonus bucks for associates? We suppose we’ll find out as bonus season unfolds.

Bonuses at the Milbank will be paid on or before December 31st, meaning associates may miss out on holiday gift spending, but will surely have a very happy new year.

Read the full bonus memo on the next page.

# Rudy Giuliani Cut Loose By Biglaw Firm 3 Years Ago... Why Is He Still Claiming To Work There?
## Pro tip: update your resume especially after being publicly denounced.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onAugust 4, 2021 at 1:13 PMAugust 4, 2021 at 3:55 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/rudy-giuliani-cut-loose-by-biglaw-firm-3-years-ago-why-is-he-still-claiming-to-work-there/&text=Rudy%20Giuliani%20Cut%20Loose%20By%20Biglaw%20Firm%203%20Years%20Ago…%20Why%20Is%20He%20Still%20Claiming%20To%20Work%20There?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/rudy-giuliani-cut-loose-by-biglaw-firm-3-years-ago-why-is-he-still-claiming-to-work-there/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/rudy-giuliani-cut-loose-by-biglaw-firm-3-years-ago-why-is-he-still-claiming-to-work-there/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Rob Kim/Getty)

Remember when Rudy Giuliani touted himself [as a cybersecurity expert](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2017/01/12/trump-names-rudy-giuliani-as-cybersecurity-adviser/) and [then butt dialed a reporter](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/rudy-giuliani-butt-dials-nbc-reporter-heard-discussing-need-cash-n1071901)? If only that was the most embarrassing [recent story about his pants](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/rudy-giuliani-scores-razzie-nomination-for-ahem-touching-performance/). Well, it turns out that his lack of tech savvy may run even deeper than a hypothetical operative’s ties to Ukrainian actors working with the Kremlin trying to pass along fake dirt on Joe Biden.

The erstwhile Trump attorney may be [scrambling for cash](https://news.yahoo.com/rudy-giuliani-legal-fund-bust-224241239.html) and [fending off a criminal probe](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/rudy-giuliani-debuts-if-you-think-i-committed-a-crime-youre-probably-really-stupid-defense/) about his we-don’t-really-call-it-“lobbying”-but-lobbying work, but you can’t keep a guy like him down! I mean, things might not be looking great for him, but he’s still got his old job… maybe?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
A quick perusal of [the former mayor’s bio](http://www.giulianisecurity.com/about/) at the eponymous Giuliani Security & Safety includes a curious detail:

Mr. Giuliani continues in his role as Chairman and CEO of Giuliani Partners LLC, a management consulting firm which he founded in 2002, as well as a Senior Advisor/Senior Chair of Firm Development at Greenberg Traurig, a law firm.

Meanwhile, Greenberg Traurig is the firm that not only cut him loose in 2018, but has repeatedly and publicly [reminded the world of this fact ever since](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/greenberg-traurig-wants-absolutely-nothing-to-do-with-rudy-giuliani/).

The firm and Mr. Giuliani parted ways in May 2018, he is neither a client nor an employee, nor affiliated in any way with the firm.

###Sponsored

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
That was Greenberg Traurig’s statement earlier this year and doesn’t leave a lot of room for interpretation.

So either Giuliani is still knowingly misleading potential clients by publicly claiming to still work with a law firm that disavowed him like a captured IMF team over 3 years ago or the cybersecurity genius hasn’t bothered to update his website bio for years. The latter would seem hard to believe until one recalls that web experts have already weighed in on the [atrocious levels of maintenance on his company website](https://qz.com/1757484/giulianis-security-company-website-gets-an-f-for-security/):

Mozilla Observatory, an online site-scanning service operated by the nonprofit company behind the Firefox web browser, rates Giuliani Security & Safety’s website an “F” for basic connection security, with a score of 0 out of 100. In a suite of 11 tests, the Giuliani Security & Safety site passes just 3, according to Mozilla.

Now that all those election suits have flamed out, this might be a good time to brush up on the website resume. And this assumes that Giuliani Security & Safety is even still in business. Google lists the company as permanently closed, while other sources say it’s still out there doing… something. Though it’s never been exactly clear [what that something really is](https://www.zdnet.com/article/nobody-seems-to-know-what-rudy-giulianis-cybersecurity-company-actually-does/).

But someone is still paying the bills for this website and it’s still touting his connection to Greenberg Traurig, which is probably news to Greenberg Traurig.

# The ATL Law Firm Gender Diversity Index (2016)
## The ATL Law Firm Gender Diversity Index is the most comprehensive and accurate database of its kind available anywhere.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 13, 2016 at 2:30 PMJune 7, 2016 at 3:08 PM
20
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/the-atl-law-firm-gender-diversity-index-2016/&text=The%20ATL%20Law%20Firm%20Gender%20Diversity%20Index%20(2016))[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/the-atl-law-firm-gender-diversity-index-2016/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/the-atl-law-firm-gender-diversity-index-2016/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Year in and year out, we watch law firm after law firm pay lip service to their commitment to diversity in the legal profession, with promises to put women attorneys on equal footing with their male counterparts, whether it be through hiring and retaining more women attorneys, promoting more women attorneys to partner, or providing more leadership positions to women attorneys. Despite these assurances, little meaningful progress has been made to improve women’s stature in the law.

How, then, can we truly compare law firms to see which ones have actually succeeded in their gender diversity efforts? While several companies have attempted to study or rank law firms on the basis of gender diversity in the past based on survey results, none have collected raw data regarding the state of the legal market — until today.

We have teamed up with [NavForward ](https://navforward.com/#/home)to categorize every lawyer in the top 1,200 firms in the country to create the ATL Law Firm Gender Diversity Index, the most comprehensive and accurate database of its kind available anywhere. The data in this study is from December 2014, and includes promotions from the entire 2014-2015 cycle (data from the 2015-2016 cycle is not included, as that cycle is not yet complete).

We’ve graded these law firms on a scale from A+ to C, based on total number of attorneys, percentage of female attorneys, percentage of female associates, percentage of female partners, and percentage of female promotions from associate to partner. We’ve further broken this list down by region, with rankings for the following markets: Atlanta; Boston; Chicago; Houston; Los Angeles; New York; Philadelphia; San Francisco; and Washington, D.C.

Congratulations to the top six firms in our overall gender diversity stats:

Firm Name	Total Attorneys	% Female Attorneys	% Female Associates	% Female Partners	% Female Promotions	Grade
Ballard Spahr	521	38	51	26	60	A+
Crowell & Moring	461	38	56	22	56	A+
Fennemore Craig	186	36	47	31	67	A+
Fragomen, Del Rey, Bernsen & Loewy	406	62	69	50	71	A+
Manatt, Phelps & Phillips	390	33	54	26	100	A+
Quarles & Brady	483	36	49	28	53	A+
We’ve classified 200,000 attorneys — how does your law firm measure up?

To find out, click [here](https://abovethelaw.com/careers/law-firm-gender-diversity-index-2016/) to access the [ATL Law Firm Gender Diversity Index](https://abovethelaw.com/careers/law-firm-gender-diversity-index-2016/).

####Topics
[ATL Law Firm Gender Diversity Index](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/atl-law-firm-gender-diversity-index/), [Ballard Spahr](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ballard-spahr/), [Ballard Spahr Stillman & Friedman](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ballard-spahr-stillman-friedman/), [Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Crowell & Moring](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/crowell-moring/), [Crowell & Moring LLP](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/crowell-moring-llp/), [Fennemore Craig](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/fennemore-craig/), [Fragomen](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/fragomen/), [Fragomen Del Rey](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/fragomen-del-rey/), [Fragomen Del Rey Bernsen & Loewy](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/fragomen-del-rey-bernsen-loewy/), [Gender](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/gender/), [Manatt](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/manatt/), [Manatt Phelps & Phillips](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/manatt-phelps-phillips/), [Midsize Firms / Regional Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/midsize-firms-regional-firms/), [NavForward](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/navforward/), [Quarles & Brady](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quarles-brady/), [Rankings](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/rankings/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/small-law-firms-topic/), [Women's Issues](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/womens-issues/)

# ABA Survey: Lawyers Are Stressed Out
## The survey results indicated that despite the high stress levels, many law firms fail to provide adequate mental health support for their employees.
By [Nicole Black](https://abovethelaw.com/author/nicoleblack/)  
onAugust 5, 2021 at 4:46 PMAugust 5, 2021 at 2:54 PM
21
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/aba-survey-lawyers-are-stressed-out/&text=ABA%20Survey:%20Lawyers%20Are%20Stressed%20Out)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/aba-survey-lawyers-are-stressed-out/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/aba-survey-lawyers-are-stressed-out/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Survey statistics from a recently released survey conducted by the American Bar Association show that lawyers were stressed out before the onset of COVID-19, and the pandemic has only made things worse. Of course, that’s not surprising since it’s safe to say that the effects of the pandemic have stressed out just about everyone one way or another!

The survey at issue — the Profile of the Profession 2021 — compiles data collected by the ABA from a number of different surveys, most of which were conducted in 2020 and 2021. In [the report](https://www.abalegalprofile.com/), you’ll find statistics on a host of issues relating to the legal profession, including lawyer demographics, the pandemic and its impact on the practice of law, lawyers’ perspectives on retirement and the future, and much more.

Because the pandemic continues to impact the legal industry and the lives and practices of lawyers, the data regarding the stress and well-being of legal professionals was of particular interest. We all know that the practice of law can be anxiety-inducing in and of itself, and as you’ll see below, the uncertainties of the pandemic have only served to exacerbate stress levels for attorneys.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Pandemic-Related Stress

First, let’s take a look at how the pandemic has affected the overall well-being of lawyers. The lawyers surveyed were asked whether the pandemic had added to their work stress levels, and more than a third (40%) reported that their overall work-related stress levels had increased.

Notably, and in line with an oft-reported pandemic trend, people of color were disproportionately affected by the pandemic’s impact, with 48% of lawyers of color sharing that work-related stressors had increased.

Similarly, the responses to this question varied significantly between men and women. More than half (52%) of women lawyers shared that their stress levels had increased, whereas only 34 percent of men did so.

Overall Stress

The disparity between women and men isn’t surprising since the survey results also showed that overall, even before the pandemic, women reported higher stress levels. Specifically, two-thirds of women (67%) reported moderate or severe stress compared with less than half of men (49%). As a result, more women than men felt burned out due to the practice of law, with 24 percent of women sharing that they’d considered leaving the legal profession due to mental health problems, burnout or stress, compared to only 17 percent of men.

The survey results also showed that the pressures of practicing law, some of which are self-imposed, can take their toll and lead to burnout. For example, when lawyers were asked to describe their work week and how they approached time off, the data showed that lawyers rarely cut themselves a break:

- 38% said they often work long hours
- 9% said they “never stop working”
- 25% said they failed to take adequate breaks during the workday
- 32% said they feel pressure to not take vacation time.
Given those responses, it’s no wonder that lawyers have high levels of burnout. Unfortunately, the survey results indicated that despite the high stress levels, many law firms fail to provide adequate mental health support for their employees. In fact, only a little more than half (56%) of lawyers surveyed agreed that their employers supported their mental health needs. One example of a failure to support lawyers is shown by the fact that only 26 percent of survey respondents reported that their law firm provides information on 12-step programs or other mental health resources.

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Concern Regarding The Return To Work

Last, but not least, as discussed above, the pandemic has only added to lawyers’ stress levels. Most recently, concerns have centered around returning to in-office work.

The future return to the office was a source of conflicting feelings for many of the lawyers surveyed. Lawyers from firms with 250 or more attorneys expressed the most concern about the return to the office. Of those lawyers, 71 percent indicated that they were concerned about safety issues related to being inside an office building during 2021 and 2022. Areas of concern included lack of ventilation and poor security in public spaces. Similar concerns were reported by lawyers from firms with 100 to 249 lawyers, 68 percent of whom were reluctant to return to the office, as were 75 percent of lawyers from firms with 50 to 99 lawyers.

In comparison, solo and small firm lawyers were less concerned. Only 42 percent of solo practitioners were reluctant to return to the office, as were just over half (54%) of lawyers from small firms with 2 to 9 attorneys.

So no matter how you slice and dice the data, lawyers are stressed out. The overall effects of the pandemic have only made things worse for many of them, and the recent uncertainty regarding the return to work isn’t helping matters.

What about you? Are you experiencing pandemic burnout? How do you feel about the return to in-office work?

[Nicole Black](http://lawtechtalk.com/) is a Rochester, New York attorney and Director of Business and Community Relations at [MyCase](http://www.mycaseinc.com/), web-based law practice management software. She’s been [blogging](http://nylawblog.typepad.com/) since 2005, has written a [weekly column](http://nydailyrecord.com/blog/tag/legal-currents/) for the Daily Record since 2007, is the author of [Cloud Computing for Lawyers](https://apps.americanbar.org/abastore/index.cfm?fm=Product.AddToCart&pid=5110724), co-authors [Social Media for Lawyers: the Next Frontier](http://www.abanet.org/abastore/index.cfm?section=main&fm=Product.AddToCart&pid=5110710), and co-authors [Criminal Law in New York](http://legalsolutions.thomsonreuters.com/law-products/Treatises/Criminal-Law-in-New-York-4th-2013-2014-ed/p/100216297). She’s easily distracted by the potential of bright and shiny tech gadgets, along with good food and wine. You can follow her on Twitter at [@nikiblack](http://twitter.com/nikiblack) and she can be reached at [niki.black@mycase.com](mailto:niki.black@mycase.com).

# Morning Docket: 04.24.23
## * Law schools defiantly bucked U.S. News and World Report. Now they face the inevitable consequences of their own actions. [[NY Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/21/us/21nat-us-news-rankings-law-medical-school.html)] * Elon Musk's management of Twitter just keeps getting worse. [[Bloomberg Law News](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/daily-labor-report/musks-twitter-layoffs-generate-thousands-of-legal-headaches)] * NFT insider trading case begins. [[Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/ex-opensea-managers-trial-kicks-off-first-nft-insider-trading-case-2023-04-24/)] * Bed Bath & Beyond files for bankruptcy amid sagging Beyond sales. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/articles/1572274)] * Associate latering down 66 percent. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2023/04/21/associate-lateral-moves-drop-66-as-firms-pivot-to-partner-focused-growth-mode/)] * Fox's Dominion settlement likely to only cost the company about three-fourths of the total. So they've got that going for them! [[Huffington Post](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/fox-dominion-settlement-lower-cost_n_6445fbebe4b011a819c22913)] * Cop who killed Breonna Taylor has a new law enforcement job because in many offices that behavior is a feature not a bug. [[Forbes](https://www.forbes.com/sites/siladityaray/2023/04/24/ex-louisville-officer-who-fatally-shot-breonna-taylor-begins-new-law-enforcement-job/?sh=26d8c1611210)]
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onApril 24, 2023 at 8:58 AMApril 24, 2023 at 9:59 AM

# Firm Announces Raises Coming In February
## Better late than never... another firm raises salaries.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 6, 2017 at 12:22 PMJanuary 6, 2017 at 6:11 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/firm-announces-raises-coming-in-february/&text=Firm%20Announces%20Raises%20Coming%20In%20February)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/firm-announces-raises-coming-in-february/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/firm-announces-raises-coming-in-february/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Just when you thought the salary increases were over, one holdout announced this week that it would join the ranks of what we’ve been calling “MoneyLaw” and pay associates the new Cravath scale of $180K/year.

At least for first-years.

At least in some offices.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
There’s a lot left unclear in this announcement, but it’s a start.

Earlier this week, [Blank Rome LLP](https://www.blankrome.com) chairman [Alan Hoffman](https://www.blankrome.com/index.cfm?contentID=10&bioID=410) informed all associates via a prerecorded message on a firmwide conference call that first-year salaries in the firm’s New York and D.C. offices would move to $180K. Meanwhile, those first-years working at the firm’s Philadelphia home office will move to $160K. Associates elsewhere will be paid the abundantly vague amount “commensurate with the market.”

That’s the good news. Left unclear of course is what happens beyond the first year. We do know that salaries beyond the first year are influenced by some alchemy of “performance” and “other factors,” so there’s bound to be some slippage from the proper Cravath scale for at least some associates. We’ve seen other firms tout their $180K number for recruiting purposes and then engage in “scrunching” behind the scenes, building a hefty gap between their mid-level and senior associate salaries and those offered by the Cravaths of the world. We won’t know more about Blank Rome’s intentions until associates get their official salary notifications in February.

But Blank Rome confirms that these raises will be retroactive to January 1st, which is terrific news for associates.

As with a lot of salary bumps at firms outside the Cravath tier, the raise came with a commensurate increase in hourly minimums, with the bonus eligibility requirement moving from 1800 to the still relatively humane 1900 hours.

But one tipster zeroed in on the most vexing part of this news for associates:

No word on what the salaries will be for 2nd years and beyond, but everyone is pretty upset that we called into hear a prerecorded message that first years are getting a market bump when a simple email would have sufficed.

Yeah, what the hell, man? And it’s not even a conference call to hear a live presentation. No, they got everyone to call in at once to listen to a prerecorded message. How are you going to pay these new salaries if you’re screwing around like this?

# No, Simpson Thacher Didn't Forget About Associate Bonuses This Thanksgiving
## Wonder no more about the Simpson bonuses!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 23, 2018 at 11:01 AMNovember 26, 2018 at 11:53 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/no-simpson-thacher-didnt-forget-about-associate-bonuses-this-thanksgiving/&text=No,%20Simpson%20Thacher%20Didn’t%20Forget%20About%20Associate%20Bonuses%20This%20Thanksgiving)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/no-simpson-thacher-didnt-forget-about-associate-bonuses-this-thanksgiving/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/no-simpson-thacher-didnt-forget-about-associate-bonuses-this-thanksgiving/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
While you were busy trying to engineer an escape from Biglaw on Wednesday in order to garner some semblance of a happy holiday, the powers-that-be at some Biglaw firms were busy finalizing associate bonus structures to make for an even more thankful celebration. Of course, in the case of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, there wasn’t too much to discuss since they just copied the [bonus schedule that Cravath ](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/breaking-cravath-announces-annual-bonuses/)set out earlier this week (which itself was a dupe of last year’s — and the year’s before that — scale).

But, in any event, here is the associate bonus structure Simpson announced before everyone left to enjoy their Thanksgiving:



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
While it may not seem exciting that the bonuses are a redux of those in recent years, you have to remember this year associates at the top Biglaw shops also saw raises. And that’s in addition to the [mid-year bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/biglaw-giant-matches-associate-raises-plus-special-summer-bonuses/) the good folks at Simpson ushered in, so the fact that year-end bonuses still match those of previous years is actually a good thing. As one tipster noted:

Happy they didn’t go down given that we got a summer bonus as well!

[(The full memo from the firm is on the next page.)](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/no-simpson-thacher-didnt-forget-about-associate-bonuses-this-thanksgiving/2/)

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# White Men Continue To Do Very Well For Themselves At Biglaw Firms
## Not surprising -- white men are still the driving force in Biglaw.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 10, 2020 at 5:16 PMNovember 10, 2020 at 4:03 PM
2
