From Pilot and Above The Law  
Barring an “all of the above,” we’ll just have to settle on (d), because Above the Law feeds on the salt ground into those wounds, and gleefully applauds the author for doing it.

The author, by the way, is an associate now formerly of Kirkland & Ellis in San Francisco. His departure memo, sent out last night, is a tour de force of a departure. So let’s get to it! Cue Alicia Keys, because THIS… BRIDGE… IS… ON… FIIIIIRRRRRREEEE…

After _____[1]_____, it is time to say goodbye to K&E….

a. recovering from amnesia and realizing that I never went to law school
b. a wonderful two months
c. thoughtful consideration over eight glasses of wine at lunch
d. laundering millions of dollars via your servers

This may be the best choice presented in the entire departure memo, because, according to LinkedIn, he’s worked at Kirkland for almost one year. Once you eliminate (b) as an option…

I am leaving to _____[2]_____.

a. pursue my dream of being crowned champion of the nineteenth season of RuPaul’s Drag Race
b. join the Trump/Pence 2016 campaign
c. [intentionally omitted]
d. judge the 2017 Eurovision Song Contest

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Hey, if someone from (b) was able to (c) Melania’s paragraph about values, they’d be in a much better place.

I have _____[3]_____my time here

a. from start-to-finish thoroughly enjoyed
b. delivery delayed literally thousands of emails during
c. somehow survived
d. developed a drinking problem as a result of

Remember those MBE questions where it seemed like multiple answers were correct but there just wasn’t that option?

and I will _____[4]_____.

a. make sure to avoid 555 California Street for the rest of my life
b. remember my time here fondly
c. steal as many office supplies as I can fit in my man purse
d. miss all of you I’ve come to know

Speaking of… is he going to remember his time fondly or miss everyone? That’s the trick! This is how you know it’s (c).

I look forward to _____[5]_____

a. (re-) starting my new (old) job
b. leaving the office today
c. never using Carpe Diem again
d. moving to New York City for its relatively more affordable housing

Looks like someone’s been reading the [ATL real estate comparison guide](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/heres-why-you-dont-deserve-the-same-raise-in-pictures/)! His old job was with Clifford Chance in New York, so if he’s heading back there he’s not escaping Carpe Diem — or some reasonable facsimile of it — anytime soon.

But it sure sounds like he’s bouncing on the whole idea of lawyerin’…

and will _____[6]_____

a. definitely call you if I screw up and require legal representation
b. crash the next open bar event
c. be leaving behind a pile of glitter in my office
d. keep in touch

We all, at least those of us he’s not abandoning at Kirkland, wish him well. It’s a fun letter, and he’ll be a wise and capable Eurovision adjudicator.

(The full email is available on the next page…)

[Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is an editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joe@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news.

# An Associate With Little Work Is A Sad Sight
## Associates who do not have much work to do might rightly feel paranoid about their situation.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onFebruary 3, 2023 at 11:48 AMFebruary 3, 2023 at 3:43 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/an-associate-with-little-work-is-a-sad-sight/&text=An%20Associate%20With%20Little%20Work%20Is%20A%20Sad%20Sight)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/an-associate-with-little-work-is-a-sad-sight/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/an-associate-with-little-work-is-a-sad-sight/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As mentioned in a previous column, law firms are not always efficient when it comes to dolling out work. Instead of having a centralized system through which partners give work to associates, most law firms simply encourage partners to give work to associates they like the most or associates that have a workplace near them in an office. As a result, some attorneys in an office might have too much work while others do not have enough to keep them busy. Of course, some people might argue that this means good attorneys will excel while bad lawyers will fall to the wayside, but this can lead to inefficiencies in how people bill hours. In any event, an associate attorney with little work is a sad sight, and partners should make sure everyone is sufficiently occupied whenever they can.

Being slow is absolutely miserable as an associate. Whenever I was slow at a law firm, my days would drag on since time moves much slower when you have little to do. Law firm life is already tedious as it is, and trying to fill time around an office without completing assignments for clients can be grueling. There is also a sense of shame associated with being slow at an office. People pull a salary regardless of how much work they are completing day to day, and it does not feel good not to be contributing to a firm by completing assignments.

Furthermore, associates who do not have much work to do might rightly feel paranoid about their situation. Associates are evaluated on the amount of billable hours they record more than any other metric. This makes a lot of sense, since associates are only valuable to law firms if they can generate revenue, and billable hours are directly connected to the amount of hours that an associate bills. If an associate does not have enough work, they might be scared that they will not meet billable hour expectations, which might mean that they are on the chopping block at a shop. In addition, attorneys might be fearful that they are slow because partners do not like their work rather than benign reasons like just being generally slow with certain types of cases.

Slow associates at law firms exhibit a variety of really sad behaviors. One of which is that slow associates need to go around an office looking for work. This is not a pleasant sight. An associate looking for more work is kind of reminiscent of Oliver Twist asking for more food, and it definitely feels like the associate is begging for something from superiors. Many times associates asked for more work in my experience, you could almost hear the desperation in their voices or a look in their eyes that they were hopeful that they could finally get some work so that they no longer needed to go around and ask for more assignments.

There are some things that associates with little work can do in order to improve their situation. Perhaps most importantly, slow associates can pitch their own assignments to partners. This not only shows initiative, which can improve the associate’s image around an office, but this can help keep the associate busy. At the beginning of my career, I worked at a law firm that was going through some tough times financially. I would regularly review the dockets of cases we were involved in so that I could be the first person to know of case developments.

If I saw a filing that could lead to a potential research project or for which a response was required, I would immediately reach out to partners in order to see if I could work on such tasks. By doing this, I was able to fill some of the time I might have otherwise spent without work. However, this can only get you so far and in many instances, budgets and other constraints limit partners from greenlighting all assignments proposed by associates.

In any case, having slow associates can be horrendous to the morale of a firm. Not only can it make people feel bad, it can also make associates mad if they have too much work to do and are not meeting expectations of partners. Accordingly, law firms should be more cognizant of how much work everyone has to do around an office and ensure that it is less likely that an associate will have too little work to complete.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. You can reach Jordan through email at [jordan@rothmanlawyer.com](mailto:jordan@rothmanlawyer.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# David Boies Scores Coup With HUGE Lateral Pickup
## Susan Estrich reunites with David Boies, years after they first worked together.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onOctober 9, 2018 at 10:56 AMOctober 22, 2018 at 4:26 PM
22
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/david-boies-scores-coup-with-huge-lateral-pickup/&text=David%20Boies%20Scores%20Coup%20With%20HUGE%20Lateral%20Pickup)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/david-boies-scores-coup-with-huge-lateral-pickup/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/david-boies-scores-coup-with-huge-lateral-pickup/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

David Boies

“I’ve been trying to recruit her for over 30 years,” David Boies told me. How did he manage to finally succeed? “I don’t know. Is it possible to just wear somebody down?” he said with a laugh.

However it happened, his decades of labor have finally paid off. Today, Boies Schiller announced that they have coaxed Susan Estrich to join the firm’s appellate practice in the Los Angeles office, completing Boies’s mission to work with Susan again after first working with her on the Senate Judiciary Committee in the late 70s.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Estrich doesn’t credit this move to being worn down. In fact, she may just be following the advice of her old boss. While she clerked for Justice Stevens, a pair of young lawyers working at the Judiciary Committee asked to interview her over lunch with the caveat that they wanted to meet her in the Supreme Court cafeteria. Estrich was pretty confident these two, a couple of fellows named David Boies and Stephen Breyer, were covertly angling to have lunch with Justice Stevens. After a delightful lunch, Justice Stevens told Estrich to accept the job offer the two had brought. “You should take it,” he said. “I think those guys have great futures.”

Supreme advice aside, Estrich sees the fit with Boies Schiller as a perfect match with her life philosophy: “so much of life is taking advantage of opportunities when you see them.” She described meeting up with Boies recently, “and it felt like coming home. He offered a chance for a new chapter for me, and I’m excited about a new chapter.”

And it’s a new chapter for Boies Schiller too. As Jonathan Schiller said, “I look forward to trying cases and arbitral hearings with Susan all over the world. Susan will also strengthen our growing California practice.” That California practice is a key part of this move. We’ve been watching the firm [bolster its California presence](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/boies-schiller-picks-up-a-top-boutique/) over the last several months, and now they can add Susan Estrich to the office to help it grow.

Estrich may famously believe that people [shouldn’t go to law school](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/08/quinn-emanuel-partner-warns-dont-go-to-law-school/), but she seems to be making a pretty good career out of it herself. And she’s a little surprised at that fact, describing the bulk of her career as trying to do anything with her law degree except practice — jumping from her Supreme Court clerkship with Justice Stevens to the Senate to working on Ted Kennedy’s presidential campaign, managing the Dukakis campaign, and serving as a law professor.

But despite trying to stay away from it, when she found herself joining private practice with Quinn Emanuel 10 years ago, she discovered to her surprise that “I actually like it.”


Susan Estrich

As Estrich departs Quinn Emanuel, she leaves a legacy of high-profile representations, including everyone from Home Depot to Mattel in its epic tussles over Bratz to Roger Ailes in his sexual harassment fight. At the time she took on Ailes, I quipped that, in that specific job, I wasn’t wishing her much success. But that’s a wholly different matter than blaming a lawyer for taking on a controversial client.

When it comes to criticism over controversial clients, Estrich has something else in common with Boies, who’s taken recent knocks in the mainstream press and, frankly, I don’t get it. Boies weathered a torrent of criticism over his representation of Harvey Weinstein and his work for Theranos. Sure, signing off on a security firm of former spies that, among other things, apparently interfered with the work of another Boies client was a mistake — one that Boies admits — but the bulk of the commentary around Boies these days seems more incensed that Boies would take on these hard cases at all. As a recent [New York Times article explored](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/21/business/david-boies-pleads-not-guilty.html), that reasoning never really resonated with most of us in the legal community, who take it as a given that lawyers have to zealously represent clients — often troubling ones. Lawyers may want to steer clear of representations that [undermine their specific brand](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/mother-knows-best-gloria-allred-disses-daughters-decision-to-rep-harvey-weinstein/), but lawyers like Boies and Estrich are high-end, Biglaw advocates whose careers are built on representing to the hilt people and institutions that need legal help and are willing to pay for the best.

And with Susan joining the team, Boies Schiller further solidifies itself as one of the best from coast to coast.

# Stroock Reportedly Cut Pay, Hours As It Struggled To Find Merger Partner
## Yikes. Wonder what the firm's finances are looking like right now....
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 16, 2023 at 1:43 PMOctober 16, 2023 at 1:20 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/stroock-reportedly-cut-pay-hours-as-it-struggled-to-find-merger-partner/&text=Stroock%20Reportedly%20Cut%20Pay,%20Hours%20As%20It%20Struggled%20To%20Find%20Merger%20Partner)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/stroock-reportedly-cut-pay-hours-as-it-struggled-to-find-merger-partner/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/stroock-reportedly-cut-pay-hours-as-it-struggled-to-find-merger-partner/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Stroock & Stroock & Lavan may have found its (latest) [“non-exclusive” match in Pillsbury Winthrop](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/stroock-is-talking-to-another-am-law-100-firm-about-merging-but-its-not-exclusive/), but the firm had been leaking lawyers like a sieve ever since it broke up with Nixon Peabody, and news now comes that the firm had reportedly cut pay and hours for its most senior staff members while in search for another business suitor.

The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/10/13/stroock-cut-pay-and-hours-of-senior-staff-as-merger-talks-drag-on/) provides additional details on these rumors of the firm’s fraught finances:

Some staff have seen their pay cut by as much at 60%, sources said, and certain teams are working on a near skeleton staff. It’s unclear whether the firm has reinstated any hours and pay to those affected since July.

Law.com previously reported that two senior staffers and one junior staffer departed the firm in August. It’s not clear whether those departures are related to the whittling of pay and hours for senior staff.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Recall that [Stroock conducted layoffs](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/stroock-layoffs/) among both staff and attorneys to kick off 2023, and that was just the start of the firm’s personnel losses. Considering all of attorneys and staff who have left since then, and with pay cuts now on the table, it’s no wonder that former employees saw the firm [headed for certain disaster](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/stroocks-new-merger-partner-means-the-firm-may-not-face-bankruptcy-dissolution/) without a viable merger partner.

Once again, best of luck to Stroock as it embarks on yet another merger journey — it sounds like the firm could use all the luck it can get.

# Here Are The Law Firms Donald Trump Is Paying With His Campaign Donations
## Jones Day has debased itself. Will McDermott Will & Emery be next?
By [Elie Mystal](https://abovethelaw.com/author/elie-mystal/)  
onApril 16, 2018 at 12:12 PMApril 17, 2018 at 9:37 AM
81
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/here-are-the-law-firms-donald-trump-is-paying-with-his-campaign-donations/&text=Here%20Are%20The%20Law%20Firms%20Donald%20Trump%20Is%20Paying%20With%20His%20Campaign%20Donations)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/here-are-the-law-firms-donald-trump-is-paying-with-his-campaign-donations/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/here-are-the-law-firms-donald-trump-is-paying-with-his-campaign-donations/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[BuzzFeed reports](https://www.buzzfeed.com/tariniparti/trump-campaign-spending?utm_term=.tr8KOXPvBr#.shV2Mn0Lyl) that around 20 percent of Trump’s campaign spending this year has gone to his legal fees. A big difference between Trump-the-Businessman versus Trump-the-President seems to be that President Trump actually pays his legal bills. So… people change, I guess.

Trump’s 2020 campaign to re-elect has already spent $835,000 on legal fees in 2018, though some of it was almost certainly for services rendered in 2017. Here are the firms that have profited the most from Trump’s troubles:

Trump campaign legal expenses, first quarter, 2018:

JONES DAY: $345,000+
LAROCCA HORNIK: $185,000+
HARDER LLP: $93,000+
SCHERTLER & ONORATO: $65,000+
VAN HOY: $58,000+
BELKIN BURDEN: $40,000+
THE TRUMP CORPORATION: $24,000+
MCDERMOTT WILL & EMERY: $13,000+
SEYFARTH: $1,300+

— Chris Geidner (@chrisgeidner) [April 15, 2018](https://twitter.com/chrisgeidner/status/985605786209542145?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Last week, we reported that Jones Day was [absolutely hammered in our ATL Power 100 rankings](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/above-the-law-power-100-law-firm-rankings-are-out/), largely because their “reputation” scores suffered. Taking $345,000 of Trump’s white grievance money isn’t going to help matters.

I wonder if Jones Day will be a cautionary tale for McDermott Will & Emery. You can see that MWE hasn’t done a lot of work for Trump so far. But MWE partner [Todd Harrison](https://www.mwe.com/en/team/h/harrison-todd-r) has been all over the Trump attempt to assert privilege over the documents seized from Michael Cohen’s offices. Harrison has been out front, carrying Trump’s water that somebody other than the Department of Justice’s taint team has to determine which documents are privileged.

McDermott hasn’t promoted its association with Trump the way Jones Day did. That might make a big difference in the recruiting and lateral market. But every time some Trump argument shows up on MWE letterhead, more people will be turned off from the firm.

Trump isn’t a regular client. He’s a deeply divisive figure who represents white supremacy, sexual predation, and the attack on the rule of law (to some). Representing him carries unique reputational risks.

# Appreciate Lawyers Who Have Swagger
## Lawyers should not be afraid to let their swagger show while practicing law.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onDecember 22, 2021 at 1:44 PMDecember 22, 2021 at 12:52 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/appreciate-lawyers-who-have-swagger/&text=Appreciate%20Lawyers%20Who%20Have%20Swagger)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/appreciate-lawyers-who-have-swagger/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/appreciate-lawyers-who-have-swagger/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As many attorneys and staff know from firsthand experience, the legal profession can be extremely boring at times. Even though movies and television shows sometimes glorify the work of lawyers, and focus on the parts of the profession that have tons of drama, the reality is that many attorneys conduct mundane tasks on a day-to-day basis. As a result, it is always refreshing to see a lawyer who has swagger and acts in an entertaining and flamboyant fashion since this breaks the monotony of legal practice and might lead the lawyer to achieve more for his or her clients.

The first time I encountered a lawyer who had swagger was while watching “Breaking Bad” in law school. Most people know the Saul Goodman character of the show, the somewhat shady criminal lawyer who helps many of the main characters accomplish their illicit deeds. Of course, it is not a good idea to glorify criminality, and we should all remember that Saul Goodman does not represent the legal profession well in how he violated professional ethics and broke the law.

However, Saul Goodman (and Jimmy McGill as explored in the prequel series “Better Call Saul) had swagger and an entertaining style in how he practiced law. He wore flashy suits which ensured that he was the center of attention when he traveled to court. In addition, he constantly made jokes with everyone he talked to, which added a level of levity that made accomplishing difficult tasks a little easier. People might be more willing to deal with an entertaining lawyer like him than any of the drab pencil-pushers attorneys encounter every day.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Of course, Saul Goodman is a fictional character, but some lawyers I have encountered in my career also have swagger, and this makes it a treat to encounter these attorneys in the legal profession. One time, I was walking to court, and I noticed an attorney drive by in an absolutely amazing car. The vehicle was a super-expensive sports car, and in the words of Silicon Valley, [it had doors that open like this.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0oV4IVy8tvE) The paint job on the car was sure to catch anyone’s attention. When the lawyer stepped out of the car, he was wearing a flamboyant suit that would definitely attract attention.

Sure, some people would call this lawyer a show off for driving to court in a car that probably cost more than the amount of money I needed to borrow to attend law school. However, this lawyer had style, and it was a lot of fun to talk to him and see his swagger. This definitely broke up the monotony of heading to court to go through the motions of yet another discovery conference.

Earlier in my career, I had an adversary who was less showy but he still had a fair amount of swagger. Pretty much every email my adversary wrote had a joke in it, and sometimes they would be laugh-out-loud funny. Not everyone appreciated this lawyer’s humor, and in conversations with all of the attorneys involved in the case, some of the other lawyers were not fans of the antics of our adversary.

However, it was a real treat for me to work with this lawyer. Sometimes, I do not like hopping on a call with adversaries, since they will invariably include the same old pleasantries and then hashing out boring details about a case with which I am involved. Nevertheless, whenever I spoke to this adversary, I looked forward to it, since I knew I would probably be laughing during our call and come away from it with a positive experience.

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Such swagger probably helped this adversary’s client too. It is best if lawyers involved in a case have a solid connection and feel comfortable speaking to one another to hash things out. Taking a lighthearted and entertaining approach to conducting business can help ensure that lawyers feel comfortable reaching out to one another on a case.

Of course, swagger is hard to teach, and it is not a skill that is easily acquired. I remember one time, a boss I had earlier in my career talked about a new initiative he was advancing. To make a joke or keep things light, at the end of a mission statement, he said something along the lines of “and we are going to have fun doing this” to which no one in the audience reacted positively. And in some instances, it is more appropriate to be serious and not display swagger in the practice of law.

However, lawyers should not be afraid to let their swagger show while practicing law. Not only will such efforts eliminate some of the boring aspects of practicing law, but keeping things light and entertaining can have a positive impact on a representation.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. You can reach Jordan through email at [jordan@rothmanlawyer.com](mailto:jordan@rothmanlawyer.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# If Biglaw Firms Want Lawyers Back In The Office, They Better Make It Worth Their While
## How can law firm leaders make the office a 'destination' for associates?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 26, 2021 at 4:16 PMOctober 26, 2021 at 3:01 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/if-biglaw-firms-want-lawyers-back-in-the-office-they-better-make-it-worth-their-while/&text=If%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Want%20Lawyers%20Back%20In%20The%20Office,%20They%20Better%20Make%20It%20Worth%20Their%20While)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/if-biglaw-firms-want-lawyers-back-in-the-office-they-better-make-it-worth-their-while/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/if-biglaw-firms-want-lawyers-back-in-the-office-they-better-make-it-worth-their-while/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
You now have to justify whatever their commute is. You have to say, ‘What’s it worth it to me as an individual to come in and do that.’ I think you’re going to see a lot more focus on serendipitous interactions, driving people through the space through the course of the day.

— Tom Fulcher, vice chairman at Savills and chairman of its legal tenant practice group, offering his thoughts on what it’s going to take for law firms to [bring people back to the office](https://www.law.com/2021/10/25/how-to-justify-the-commute-law-firms-are-trying-to-make-the-office-better-than-home/), after so much time spent working from home due to the pandemic.

# Morning Docket: 05.03.19
## * "Karaoke, ax-throwing sites want to sell beer under Utah law." Obviously one of those raises way more safety concerns for innocent bar patrons than the other -- let the ax places sell beer. [[Fox News](https://www.foxnews.com/us/karaoke-ax-throwing-sites-want-to-sell-beer-under-utah-law)] * Overrated: This whole affair has [hurt Bill Barr's reputation](https://twitter.com/JosephPatrice/status/1123717606551191552). Underrated: This whole affair has hurt Emmet Flood's reputation. [[Politico](https://www.politico.com/story/2019/05/02/white-house-lawyer-mueller-report-1299251)] * Ninth Circuit cuts off copyright claims that could have been brought as part of an earlier patent suit. Everyone should be a lot more troubled that copyright is bleeding into patent so much that this was even a discussion. [[The Recorder](https://www.law.com/2019/05/02/copyright-suit-against-microsoft-is-precluded-by-earlier-patent-suit/)] * Facial recognition software has some well-documented problems and now regulation is coming. [[Legaltech News](https://www.law.com/2019/05/02/retailers-using-facial-recognition-should-be-wary-of-illinois-and-followers/)] * Diverse legal teams are happier. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1156084/diverse-legal-teams-take-work-top-in-house-attys-say)] * DLA Piper leans into tech development. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/05/02/hedging-against-recession-dla-piper-bets-on-data-and-tech-programs/)] * George Carlin's impact on legal history. [[Biography](https://www.biography.com/news/george-carlin-seven-words-supreme-court)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 3, 2019 at 8:58 AM
0

# Bankruptcy Option Won't Be 'Pretty' For Stroock
## Here's why Stroock will do anything it can to stay away from bankruptcy.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 1, 2023 at 5:18 PMNovember 1, 2023 at 3:50 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/bankruptcy-option-wont-be-pretty-for-stroock/&text=Bankruptcy%20Option%20Won’t%20Be%20‘Pretty’%20For%20Stroock)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/bankruptcy-option-wont-be-pretty-for-stroock/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/bankruptcy-option-wont-be-pretty-for-stroock/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

Bankruptcy is what you want to avoid at all costs. The trustee in law firm bankruptcies claws back compensation against individual partners. So that is why, if you’re a law firm or an accounting firm, bankruptcy cases are not pretty.

— [Leslie Corwin](https://www.duanemorris.com/attorneys/lesliecorwin.html), a lawyer at Duane Morris who’s overseen numerous law firm wind-downs, in comments given to [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/death-of-a-law-firm-how-stroock-collapsed-after-150-years) on why Stroock & Stroock & Lavan will be trying its hardest to [stay out of bankruptcy](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/stroock-working-on-wind-down-trying-to-keep-firm-out-of-bankruptcy/) during its [dissolution and wind down](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/stroock-to-dissolve-close-its-doors-after-nearly-150-years-in-business/).

# Not All Biglaw Firms Are Pushing Their First-Year Start Dates Into 2021
## A handful that we know of are starting remotely this fall -- and one firm is even onboarding associates in person.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 19, 2020 at 11:44 AMNovember 18, 2020 at 11:37 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/not-all-biglaw-firms-are-pushing-their-first-year-start-dates-into-2021/&text=Not%20All%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Are%20Pushing%20Their%20First-Year%20Start%20Dates%20Into%202021)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/not-all-biglaw-firms-are-pushing-their-first-year-start-dates-into-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/not-all-biglaw-firms-are-pushing-their-first-year-start-dates-into-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw firms across the country have delayed the start dates of their incoming associates to January 2021 (or later) out of an abundance of caution thanks to the coronavirus. At the time these announcements were made, remote work was still new and we were in a state of economic upheaval. Now that almost a year has passed, these COVID accommodations are no longer so novel and there’s plenty of of work to be had. That said, several firms have decided to start their first-years remotely in 2020 — and one is even bringing its freshmen attorneys into the office.

Biglaw firms that are onboarding their incoming associates in 2020 include:

- Fenwick & West
- Start date of October 19
- Goodwin Procter
- Start date of October 19
- Latham & Watkins
- Start date in late October/early November
- McDermott Will & Emery
- Start date of October 14 or January 2021 (up to associates)
- McGuireWoods
- Start date in November — in person, if possible
- Morgan, Lewis & Bockius
- Start date sometime in November
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
UPDATE (1:00 p.m.): Sources tell us Kirkland & Ellis is doing remote onboarding for first-years in New York today. Locke Lord also started first years today as well. Jones Day will start its first-years nationwide on November 9 (whether they’ll be remote or not is a different story).

The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/10/16/as-others-delay-these-firms-proceed-with-first-year-onboarding-at-a-distance/) has more information on what’s going on at McGuireWoods:

The firm has been working at a roughly 30% occupancy rate as of late, said managing partner Tracy Walker. Much like its [hybrid summer associate program](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/08/27/fly-fishing-and-all-night-layovers-how-mcguirewoods-got-face-to-face-with-summer-associates-despite-covid-challenges/), the policy in completely voluntary, Walker added.

“We have these 40 new people coming in, and like our summer associates we want an environment where they can excel,” Walker said. “Working remotely in teams is a lot easier when the team [members] know each other.”

Walker added that the firm made the decision in May to start its associates in the fall, after projecting its finances in the depths of the pandemic-induced recession. He said it was important that associates had the certainty and job security to hold them steady through the extremely uncertain summer.

Does Walker have any concerns about starting new associates in person? “Looking back now in mid-October, I believe we made the right decision,” he said.

# Folks, Let's Not Shame People For Getting Vaccines
## But, seriously, if you've got the vaccine, show a little decorum.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMarch 4, 2021 at 10:45 AMMarch 5, 2021 at 9:36 AM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/folks-lets-not-shame-people-for-getting-vaccines/&text=Folks,%20Let’s%20Not%20Shame%20People%20For%20Getting%20Vaccines)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/folks-lets-not-shame-people-for-getting-vaccines/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/folks-lets-not-shame-people-for-getting-vaccines/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As everyone sits around waiting for vaccines to end their COVID nightmare, there’s a strong impulse to heap unending scorn on people getting vaccinated before you. Especially if those people go around publicly crowing about it. Seriously, old NFL celebration penalty rules apply: collect your vaccine and walk stoically back to the sidelines like a professional.

So if people post happy movies of their “[Biglaw firm] Vaccine Party!!” on their wall, we can embrace how unbelievably tacky that is and definitely ask why the hell they feel the need to name the firm as if it’s a cult that defines their very humanity, but we can’t really shame them for getting the vaccine itself.

I’ve gotten my first dose. As a dashing, vibrant, young writer who can work remotely indefinitely, that may not seem fair. But I have a genetic heart condition whose top identified symptom is “instant death,” so I get to be on the list. Lucky me! The point is that we don’t know what conditions the folks posting this might have and it’s a bit ableist to presume they don’t have something that makes them a priority.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Now, I certainly do wonder why the firm would find its name in a vaccine celebration. I like my employers but would never post “Above the Law Vaccine Party!!” anywhere. I mean, I guess I just did write those words, but you get my point. It kind of reads as if a major law firm used its connections to jump the line in a state whose vaccine rollout is infamously slipshod, in this case, a state that doesn’t prioritize K-12 teachers despite requiring in-person instruction for months. But the firm doesn’t control the governor’s office (well, actually given the governor involved and the firm involved, they might…) and if they can get people vaccinated at all it’s better than wasting vaccines like the state’s doing every day.

I understand the prioritization system but at the end of the day, everyone needs to go get their vaccine. “Herd immunity” got a bad rap because Donald Trump tried to use it as scientific cover for “doing absolutely nothing,” but it’s a real thing and it’s how vaccination actually works. Your individual vaccine may not stop the virus but everyone’s vaccines together cuts off its access to the hosts it needs to survive. I’d much rather see “[Biglaw firm] Vaccine Party!!” than the TikTok where an associate breaks down how Bill Gates invented COVID so he can microchip everyone. If I have to suffer through a gauche celebration video to know that people are at least being responsible, I’ll take it.

So as much as we’d all like to dunk on the classless display of a vaccine celebration party that may or may not be thanking the firm for getting you ahead of the line, we just can’t do it. This is a bad display, but we’ll just roll our eyes and thank you for taking the disease seriously right now when so many people aren’t.

# 4 Silly Things Clients Say
## Mark Herrmann has been doing this for too long to hear the same things over and over again.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onNovember 28, 2016 at 10:02 AM
7
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/4-silly-things-clients-say/&text=4%20Silly%20Things%20Clients%20Say)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/4-silly-things-clients-say/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/4-silly-things-clients-say/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I’m tired of it.

I’ve been doing this for too long to hear silly clients say the same things over and over again.

I got tired of repeating the same words to young associates, and I wrote [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762) so associates could read the book instead of forcing me to repeat myself.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Now I’m writing this column; maybe I can send it to silly clients and not have to repeat myself.

Silly clients: Don’t say these things!

First: “Sure, sue ’em! Just don’t go to court and lose.”

Look: Litigation is a crapshoot. I’ve never seen a case where my chance of winning was more than 90 percent or less than 10 percent. We sometimes lose cases that are a lock. And we sometimes win cases in which we have no hope.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Just don’t bet on it.

So I can’t tell you that we’ll go to court and not lose. I can tell you only that we’ll go to court and have a strong chance of winning.

Don’t ask for more than that.

Silly client.

Second: “Smitty says our competitor cheated! Why haven’t we sued ’em already?”

###Sponsored
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Because Smitty says a lot of stuff. Some of it’s true; some of it’s not. Before we go into court, I’d like to confirm, if possible, that Smitty is speaking the truth this time. Better yet, I’d like Smitty’s version of the truth to be supported by contemporaneous written evidence. Please let me kick the tires before we sue.

Everybody has rumors; we need evidence. And the fact that Smitty says so isn’t evidence. (Well, technically, I guess, it is evidence. But Smitty is sure gonna look like a jerk on the witness stand when it turns out that his memory is dead wrong.)

So cool your jets.

Silly client.

Third: “I know the dispute is about an unrelated issue. But just stop paying him under the contract. That’ll increase our leverage!”

Yeah, it’ll increase our leverage. But it’ll also get us sued for breach of contract, and we’ll have no defense in that case.

If we’re mad at the other guy for reasons unrelated to the contract, we probably have to fight over the issue that makes us mad. We can’t just stop paying under the unrelated contract.

Doing everything we can to create leverage doesn’t always create leverage.

Silly client.

Finally: “We don’t owe him that money. Don’t pay him a penny! Not a penny!”

Maybe.

I’ve heard countless people who look just like you scream, “Don’t pay him a penny!” Six months later, when we’re paying hundreds of thousands of dollars in defense costs and we’re up to our eyeballs in discovery, those countless people are all asking, “Why the hell did we do this? What’s wrong with you?”

It ain’t me.

I know that we’re [mad as hell and not gonna take it anymore](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rGIY5Vyj4YM).

And for a very few issues — matters of principle for which we really will pay [“millions for defense, but not one cent for tribute”](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Goodloe_Harper) — we won’t pay a penny.

But for most cases, we’re doing a cost-benefit analysis. If we can get out of the case for a couple thousand bucks, and it will cost us tens of thousands to defend it, and we’re in a jurisdiction where the winning party doesn’t recover its legal fees from the loser, then we’re pretty unlikely to refuse to pay a penny. Paying a penny that you think you don’t owe may offend you, but it’s the way of the world.

Trust me. I’ve been there before.

But maybe you haven’t. Or maybe you have, and you don’t remember.

Silly client.

Mark Herrmann spent 17 years as a partner at a leading international law firm and is now responsible for litigation and employment matters at a large international company. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762) and [Inside Straight: Advice About Lawyering, In-House And Out, That Only The Internet Could Provide](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1614385394/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1614385394&linkCode=as2&tag=dealbreaker-20) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# 4 Best Practices For Biglaw Firms That Are Weathering The Storm Well
## What should successful firms be doing to reassure and support their employees during these tumultuous times?
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onMay 5, 2020 at 5:17 PMMay 7, 2020 at 5:10 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/4-best-practices-for-biglaw-firms-that-are-weathering-the-storm-well/&text=4%20Best%20Practices%20For%20Biglaw%20Firms%20That%20Are%20Weathering%20The%20Storm%20Well)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/4-best-practices-for-biglaw-firms-that-are-weathering-the-storm-well/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/4-best-practices-for-biglaw-firms-that-are-weathering-the-storm-well/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Based on [recent headlines](https://abovethelaw.com/biglaw/), a casual observer could conclude that Biglaw is in a state of meltdown — but that wouldn’t be correct. As I said in a recent [interview with Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/us-law-week/david-lat-recovers-returns-to-an-industry-upended-by-contagion), although the legal industry currently faces “a time of uncertainty,” it’s “not in freefall.”

Take a closer look at the firms that have announced cost-cutting measures such as layoffs, furloughs, and compensation cuts. The roundups [here at Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/the-covid-crisis-law-firm-layoff-tracker-whats-your-firm-doing-to-survive/) and [over at the American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/04/20/pay-cuts-layoffs-and-more-how-law-firms-are-managing-the-pandemic/) list 76 and 70 firms, respectively. But a number of the mentioned firms are small firms, midsize firms, or even overseas entities. If you exclude those firms, you’re probably talking about, at most, a third of the Am Law 200.

The fact that most Am Law 200 firms have not had to implement any cost-cutting measures suggests that a significant number of Biglaw firms are weathering the current storm reasonably well. To be sure, the list of firms engaged in belt-tightening grows each week, and many analysts believe that we’re seeing only the tip of the iceberg. But it’s also worth noting that [several firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/the-biglaw-firms-rolling-out-good-news-for-now/?rf=1) feel comfortable enough with the condition of their coffers to announce to their employees that they will not be cutting salaries or conducting layoffs.

Now, these “no layoffs” assurances aren’t legally enforceable, and those of us who were around during the last recession can recall how some firms that made such promises wound up going back on them. But it’s safe to say that at least some firms will emerge from the current crisis relatively unscathed, as is the case with pretty much every downturn.

For firms that are in the fortunate position of holding up well, here are four recommendations for how to use the current crisis to enhance employee loyalty, burnish your firm’s reputation, and do the right thing:

1. Make gestures of generosity, if you can afford them.

These are trying times for many American families. And while households with at least one Biglaw lawyer or staff member are among the most fortunate, this doesn’t mean that they’re immune to economic difficulty.

Imagine a family of four where one parent is a Biglaw administrative assistant and the other parent just got laid off from a job as a restaurant manager. Or picture a family that’s a bit more privileged, a Biglaw associate married to a journalist who, while not laid off, just got [hit with a pay cut](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/10/business/media/news-media-coronavirus-jobs.html). These families still have kids to support and bills to pay — and they could even have unanticipated new costs, such as medical bills related to coronavirus treatment.

They could use whatever help they can get from the firm. So kudos to those firms that have stepped up to the plate with such measures as [bonuses to help out with unexpected expenses](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/prestigious-firm-bucking-the-covid-19-austerity-trend-with-special-bonuses-and-tech-budgets/?rf=1) or [technology stipends](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/covid-19-tech-stipends-all-the-rage-in-biglaw/) to help employees work more efficiently from home.

Even more modest measures go a long way in terms of increasing employee appreciation and loyalty. For example, some firms have sent meals or care packages to employees who they knew had, or had a family member who had, COVID-19. These gestures aren’t expensive, but they are deeply appreciated by those who receive them.

2. Be understanding and flexible regarding the challenges your employees face.

My colleagues and I speak to many associates in our roles as legal recruiters. These days, because lateral hiring of associates has slowed, many of our conversations are check-ins, as opposed to discussions about specific jobs.

I checked in recently with one associate who expressed some frustration about their firm. The firm seems to be doing well and hasn’t announced any austerity measures. But what this associate found frustrating is the firm’s acting as if it’s “business as usual” — when, for many associates, it’s not.

This associate is a working parent, and their spouse works as well. They have a young child and, because of the quarantine in New York, no child care. They’re both working remotely while also dealing with the added challenge of caring for their child, which means that getting work done is much harder than usual. It would be nice if the firm acknowledged the challenges that associates and staffers face right now — in terms of child care, elder care, or sick family members, to name a few — and reassured them that the current circumstances would be taken into account when evaluating performance.

For example, take the issue of billable hours. Should billable-hour requirements be waived or pro-rated to reflect the difficulty of accumulating billables while dealing with many other priorities? It’s an issue firms should start considering, even if the end of the year is still far away.

3. Communicate, communicate, communicate.

This point flows from the preceding one — and, unlike giving a tech stipend or pro-rating hours requirements, it costs a firm truly nothing. When in doubt, firms should communicate more rather than less; a little communication goes a long way.

Even during normal times, law firms have never gotten high marks for transparency. And in times of great uncertainty and anxiety for lawyers and staff, clear communications about where the firm stands and what its plans for the future are matter more than ever. We certainly know that associates at [firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/biglaw-firm-assures-associates-they-will-not-cut-salaries-or-furlough-lawyers/) that have been [more transparent](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/the-biglaw-firms-rolling-out-good-news-for-now/) greatly appreciate their firms’ honesty, openness, and reassurance.

4. Step up your pro bono game.

During difficult times like these, the need for pro bono work is greater than ever. And because of the slowness that at least some lawyers and practice areas are experiencing, many lawyers have more free time to spend on pro bono matters.

A number of firms have risen to the occasion. For example, some [34 law firms](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/03/27/law-firm-coalition-launched-national-pro-bono-campaign-to-support-small-biz/), including Kirkland & Ellis, Willkie Farr, Goodwin, and Covington, have joined together with the Lawyers for Good Government Foundation to help small business owners navigate the complexities of the federal government’s COVID-19 stimulus package (which isn’t easy to figure out, as explained in this [client memo](https://www.bsfllp.com/news-events/federal-government-updates-paycheck-protection-program-creating-significant-regulatory-risk-for-borrowers.html) by Jesse Panuccio and Simon Leen of Boies Schiller). The small-business pro bono program got started here in New York City, where Kirkland & Ellis pro bono counsel Jacqueline Haberfeld and other law firm representatives approached the City Bar Justice Center with the idea.

As Brad Karp, chairman of Paul Weiss — a longtime leader in pro bono work, which in March launched an online [Coronavirus Relief Center](https://www.paulweiss.com/practices/transactional/coronavirus-covid-19-relief-center/practice-overview/relief-center) to help individuals and small businesses — put it in a recent [Q&A with Law.com](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2020/05/04/paul-weiss-rifkind-wharton-garrison/), “Millions of Americans face economic ruin; gratuitous actions by state and federal authorities put inmates, migrants and others at extreme risk; and our democratic institutions are being undermined. If we, as lawyers, don’t step up to safeguard the rule of law and those in need, who will?”

The answer should be: all law firms and lawyers. Yes, it’s important for law firms to look after and support their own people during these trying times. But it’s also critical for Biglaw firms, who are in a relatively privileged position compared to many other businesses and industries, to look beyond themselves and to help their communities and country.

At some point in time — hopefully sooner than later, although right now it’s anyone’s guess — the COVID-19 pandemic and its economic fallout will be behind us. If you’re a law firm leader, you’ll be asked, “What did you and your firm do during the crisis?” So take actions today that will allow you to answer this question with pride tomorrow.

[David Lat](https://davidlat.com/), the founding editor of Above the Law, is a [writer](https://davidlat.com/writing/), [speaker](https://davidlat.com/speaking/), and [legal recruiter at Lateral Link](https://www.mainspringlegal.com/team/david-lat/), where he is a managing director in the New York office. David’s book, [Supreme Ambitions: A Novel](http://bit.ly/SupremeAmbitions) (2014), was described by the New York Times as “the most buzzed-about novel of the year” among legal elites. David previously worked as a federal prosecutor, a litigation associate at Wachtell Lipton, and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://bit.ly/2BMTF1R), [LinkedIn](http://bit.ly/2E9v0tq), and [Facebook](http://bit.ly/2nxIENN), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@laterallink.com](mailto:dlat@laterallink.com).

# More Law Firms Should Schedule Happy Hours For Attorneys And Staff
## If law firms are inclined to host law firm happy hours, a few things should be kept in mind to ensure success.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onMarch 8, 2023 at 4:16 PMMarch 8, 2023 at 3:49 PM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/more-law-firms-should-schedule-happy-hours-for-attorneys-and-staff/&text=More%20Law%20Firms%20Should%20Schedule%20Happy%20Hours%20For%20Attorneys%20And%20Staff)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/more-law-firms-should-schedule-happy-hours-for-attorneys-and-staff/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/more-law-firms-should-schedule-happy-hours-for-attorneys-and-staff/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Now that law firm offices are reopening after the COVID-19 pandemic, attorneys are beginning to socialize more like they did several years ago. Many lawyers are informally catching up with coworkers, and this has a positive impact on morale and fostering a team spirit at law firms. Some law firms sponsor regular happy hours for their associates so that people who work at a firm can interact in a more casual setting. More law firms should consider sponsoring such events since they can make it more fun to come to an office and can help attorneys interact outside of a typical office setting.

Before starting my own law firm about four years ago, I worked at a few shops that had regular law firm happy hours. When I was in Biglaw, I worked at a shop that had a huge happy hour on the third Thursday of every month. I think that the law firm called this “Third Thursdays” or something similar. The happy hour took place inside our office in a space that was used for social settings, and it usually included a selection of beer, nonalcoholic beverages, and a bunch of solid food offerings.

I really looked forward to Third Thursdays, since it was a good time to unwind and relax with coworkers. Such an event could lead to interactions with people that attorneys might not typically see and getting to know coworkers on a deeper level. I would be remiss if I did not mention that Third Thursdays [made the pages of Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/05/former-d-c-biglaw-staffer-sues-alleging-nasty-combination-of-drinking-and-choking-at-work/) for misconduct that allegedly occurred at this event, and safeguards need to be in place to ensure that people have fun responsibly during such activities. However, on the whole, this firm-sponsored happy hour was a great way to interact with coworkers.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
At another firm at which I worked, the happy hours were much less formal. On Friday afternoons, the law firm administrator would run to the Duane Reade drugstore across the street from our office and pick up some snacks and adult beverages. She would then go through the halls inviting anyone who was in the office on a Friday afternoon to a happy hour held either in the conference room or the managing partner’s office.

You might think that people just wanted to leave the office on a Friday afternoon and get on with their personal lives. But each week, I was shocked that a sizeable number of the attorneys and staff stayed at the office for an hour or two after working hours to drink and eat with their coworkers. This was a really good way for associates to get into the partners’ good graces, and at that firm, making connections with partners was important to getting favorable assignments. However, it was also fun for the associates to interact with each other at the law firm happy hours. I still keep in touch with tons of people from that law firm, and this could be because of the firm culture cultivated by those happy hours.

If law firms are inclined to host law firm happy hours, there are a few things they should keep in mind to ensure that they will be a success. For one, such happy hours should not take place in the office if at all possible. When people interact in an office setting, it is more difficult to be completely detached from work. However, when people interact at a bar or other similar setting, it is easier for everyone to focus on socializing rather than work. Sometimes, it is impossible to host happy hours outside of the office, either for financial or geographic reasons, but if possible, law firm happy hours should take place outside of the office.

Also, it is important that law firms make accommodations for people who do not drink due to religious custom, personal preference, and other reasons. Not everyone drinks alcoholic beverages. Some may feel pressured at law firm happy hours to drink alcohol to be part of the group, and this should be avoided as much as possible so everyone feels as comfortable as they can be at such events.

All told, law firm happy hours can have a number of benefits, and more shops should consider holding such events. Law firm happy hours can lead to an improved law firm culture and can build team spirit that can help ensure attorneys and staff are better able to serve clients.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. # Biglaw Firm Raises Salaries... For Junior Associates
## Associates don't seem happy.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 29, 2022 at 12:46 PMMarch 29, 2022 at 12:45 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/lowenstein-raises-22/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Raises%20Salaries…%20For%20Junior%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/lowenstein-raises-22/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/lowenstein-raises-22/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I’ve [said it before,](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/jones-days-225000-starting-salary-for-associates-is-not-actually-above-market/) and I’ll say it again: the easiest way to keep associates happy (re: compensation) is matching the market rate in a lockstep fashion. If you black box most associates’ salary numbers, well, there’s bound to be discontent.

That’s why, even though the Biglaw firm of Lowenstein Sandler announced raises, not everyone is thrilled.

See, it’s kind of a mixed bag. The good news for associates — well, first, second and third year associates anyway — is that the firm matched the market standard. Everyone else’s base compensation changes will be communicated individually. And, according to tipsters at the firm, folks aren’t happy:

Lowenstein Sandler matched for first three associate classes and then went to individual comp for more senior attorneys. The firm is known for paying more senior attorneys $10-50k less than market. Mid-level and senior associates (and counsel) are not happy and there are rumblings of many associates looking for new positions if the firm doesn’t increase salaries by the same amount of the new market increase (or match market).

Adding to the distrust is an updated bonus policy. The firm streamlined the process, but in a[ sample bonus grid](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/lowenstein-raises-22/3/) shared with associates, only the highest performers match the market rates. As a tipster complained:

The firm also amended its bonus structure, which is below market except for the highest performers.

Last year the firm stated it wanted to compete for the best talent, but it appears that they can’t, or won’t, compete with the best firms when it comes to salary.

The raises are retroactive to January 1. You can read the full memo [on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/lowenstein-raises-22/2/)

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Biglaw Website Fail?
## One Biglaw firm recently hit the reset button on their online presence and not everyone is happy.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 15, 2016 at 3:17 PMApril 23, 2016 at 11:21 AM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/biglaw-website-fail/&text=Biglaw%20Website%20Fail?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/biglaw-website-fail/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/biglaw-website-fail/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s 2016, so I’ll skip the intro and assume you understand that a firm’s website is important. The online representation of your brand is relevant for clients and potential clients, recruitment, and the overall reputation of the firm. But getting the perfect website, isn’t as easy as just wishing one into existence.

At the [Legal Marketing Association’s annual conference](http://www.legalmarketing.org/conference) this week, there were plenty of opportunities to learn about the value of a kickass website. And not a moment too soon, as it seems a lot of firms are undergoing a website redesign.

Content boosting brand. Show of hands of folks doing website redesign – a forest of hands shoots up in audience [#LMA16](https://twitter.com/hashtag/LMA16?src=hash)

— Oliver Thoenen (@jathoenen) [April 12, 2016](https://twitter.com/jathoenen/status/719931721550921728)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
As you might imagine, there are tricks to ensuring you have an effective website, the kind of clear, concise tool that communicates the value of the firm’s services.

Write clear, concise website and brochure content that says what you do and your value add. [#LMA16](https://twitter.com/hashtag/LMA16?src=hash) [#content](https://twitter.com/hashtag/content?src=hash) [pic.twitter.com/hd36xNwk5U](https://t.co/hd36xNwk5U)

— Danielle Diforio (@ddiforio) [April 12, 2016](https://twitter.com/ddiforio/status/719934152695349249)

And you’d best make sure you get it right because you only have 50 milliseconds to make a good impression.

It takes 50 milliseconds to process how they feel about your website. Design has to be easy to understand and digest. [@TomShapiro](https://twitter.com/TomShapiro) [#lma16](https://twitter.com/hashtag/lma16?src=hash)

— Audrea Fink (@AudreaFink) [April 12, 2016](https://twitter.com/AudreaFink/status/719973200730333184)

###Sponsored

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Amidst all the redesign going on in the industry, it makes sense that not every firm would hit it out of the park. But one Biglaw firm recently hit the reset button on their online presence, and not everyone is happy. We received this complaint from a tipster:

Cleary Gottlieb inexplicably redesigned their previously elegant website to what can only be described as what-the-actual-f**k? It looks like an ADHD 10-year-old kid from 1995 designed the layout on his $24.95 per/month AOL subscription. As an incoming associate, I am now afraid to tell people which firm I am going to for fear that they may Google them and see this nonsense. I am going to start a petition at change.org, please join me!

Why don’t you tell us how you really feel, buddy? And I’m not so sure a 48.8Kb/s dial-up connection could handle the flashy graphics. So what’s the big redo that’s creating buzz? Well, [here](https://www.clearygottlieb.com/) is the site:



The still image doesn’t reflect the rotating images on the homepage, which can be annoying. Besides that, the branding seems a little understated, and when you click on the [attorney bios](https://www.clearygottlieb.com/professionals?position=c34ba845-4e8c-4514-bc0e-30118bc532d4), the pictures seem quite a bit bigger than the understated square that white-shoe firms usually use. Not my favorite website, but I don’t think it signals the end of times like our tipster does.
